Always consistently good brunch/lunch food! Yum. The day I was there the poor waitress was running around taking care of all the tables solo. I felt bad for her!
No comment
No comment
No comment

Bright, Australian brunch spot in the heart of Soho! The inside is small so definitely make a reservation if you can. I got the purple sweet potato latte, the whipped mascarpone banana bread, and the seasonal scramble. I would probably skip the latte, it was lukewarm and tasted pretty artificial. The ribboned eggs on the seasonal scramble were done well, but the toast itself may have been toasted too long...it was nearly burnt! The star of the show was the banana bread! The coffee flavored mascarpone paired deliciously with the sweetness of the banana bread. For $11 it is quite expensive, but sharing it with the table was more than enough for me.
No comment
No comment
No comment
Delicious sandwich on fresh bread and with really nice simple side salad. Was quick and efficient, nice decor, good service. Would certainly return!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
Banana bread with espresso mascarpone -- yummy, not too rich. Steak sandwich was nice too
No comment
No comment

I can not rave Enough about this place! There were many place around but somehow my gut told me to just go there first and it do not lie. Bloody Marys were phenomenal! All the food was amazing  I would go back and recommend a 120%! Come and enjoy Brunch especially on Sunday! Loved it and all my friends did as well! Thank you for delicious food!

Casual spot with wait service and light fare in the healthy side. With that said they have an amazing banana walnut bread (gluten free) that is served warm and generously topped with espresso mascarpone, toasted buckwheat and honey. I had the pulled chicken salad bowl, not to be confused with the pulled chicken salad sandwich- both by the way are delicious and satisfying. Also tried the grass fed steak sandwich. The proteins are sandwiched between toasted sourdough bread which is crunchy and flavorful with the rest of the tasty combination of sandwich fillings. The menus do differ by location. It's worth going back to try out the other offerings at this and the other locations.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

super cute interior! i got an acai bowl and it seemed to be pretty standard. it wasn't too sweet, which i liked, but it was your typical brunch fare with a cozy atmosphere. very good place to have a nice brunch conversation
No comment

One of my favorite brunch places in a super convenient location! Been twice, loved what I had the second time around WAY more -- not sure if it was a one off thing but wouldn't really recommend the poached eggs. The proportions are totally worth it and the food is great! Always had the most wonderful experiences with the waitstaff here as well, really nice spot on a summer day!

Underrated brunch spot in Soho! After battling multiple crowded restaurants in search for a table, Two Hands could accommodate us and even inside on a chilly day. Everything on the menu looked really good. I started with a croissant, which was buttery, crispy on the outside, and delicious. For an entree I ordered the brunch special (avocado toast with smoked salmon and poached eggs). This was my perfect idea of brunch food, and it was incredible. There was a healthy serving of smoked salmon and the eggs were nicely poached. Service was friendly and I would definitely come back!
No comment
No comment
Terrible service. Average food. Not worth your time or your money. New York has too many fantastic restaurant options to waste a meal here.

I came here with a friend for a late lunch and it was pretty good. I got the market plate with scrambled eggs. The sweet potatoes were cooked and seasoned very well and I also enjoyed the kale salad, but the eggs were a bit bland. The food was overall pretty tasty, but it took quite a while to come out. Not a bad option for brunch, but not my first choice.
Super friendly and helpful staff that are clearly working hard to deal with high demand. The food was delicious and creative. I had the seasonal scramble and it was amazing.
I don't understand the previous bad review, this place is amazing! The service was outstanding and the food was absolutely delicious. Best eggs ever and I love the presentation. We will be back soon!
Great for lunch or breakfast, you feel super healthy after eating here. Staff is very friendly.

Came here for brunch with a friend and was pretty disappointed. We arrived at 11am, which was on the early side it seemed, as we didn't have to wait for a table, but there was a crowd waiting by the time we left at 12:30pm. The service is really slow as they are quite busy. I was going to order the acai bowl, but after seeing the previous review and photo of it (it looked like a frozen ice cream scoop) I decided to go for something else. I had the pulled chicken bowl, which was $18 - that's the price of a dinner entree! The food was fine, but nothing special. The restaurant is also pretty cramped, so I wouldn't recommend it for groups or for leisurely conversations. My bill was $27 for the bowl and a coffee, which is crazy high.

Absolutely love this place. Staff is excellent as is the food. Breakfast sandwich is delicious as is the BLT, and avocado toast. Coffee is always fresh and hot. This has become my Saturday morning hangout. I do a little work before my food arrives and feel like I get a leg up on the day.

This morning I had the breakfast burrito and taro latte! For the burrito I requested bacon be added, which I think was a great decision. It did have a little kick to it as there are jalapeños inside. Overall, was happy with my breakfast.

Was quiet on a Thursday morning, but the atmosphere was great, and I'm sure I had the best açai bowl I've ever had!! The staff were really friendly and encouraged me to try the DELISH taro latte. I always love coming here and this did not disappoint

this place was on my list of places to try out, there was a wait but the hosts texted me once tables were ready. I had the perfect seat and the food was so fulfilling. I had the breakfast wrap and the rosemary rosado. It was amazing. They kept everything clean and surface was more than sufficient, even being busy. I highly recommend
No comment
Had the breakfast roll and rose tea for breakfast and was delighted by the fluffiness of the egg. The spicy Mayo added flavor and heat. Delicious.
No comment
No comment

Had breakfast here this morning with my wife for the first time and everything was so good!! A handful of our friends told us the coffee was amazing here and they were right. And the food was also great. I enjoyed my breakfast burrito and my wife loved the pulled pork roll she had. Can't wait to come back here again next time we are in New York.
Good service and outdoor dining great experience. Fast and quick service thank you guys wish come back ! Stay safe
No comment

Awesome cafe in the middle of Noho. The coffee is on point, and the food is delicious and seems really healthy. The menu has a range of lighter to heavier dishes, and quite a few gluten-free and vegetarian options. Friendly and efficient service, good for a quick bite during the week.

No wait and fast service at this brand new location on Bleecker Street. The menu is consistent with the other two locations and the food is always top notch. We walked in around 1pm on the Sunday after thanksgiving and we were seated straight away, mostly due to the fact that the majority of people don't yet know about the existence of this location. We had the banana bread ($10), which comes with a mascarpone spread on top. We also had the Build Your Breakfast ($10), which comes with sourdough bread and your choice of eggs any style, and optional sides for an additional $4-$5. We opted for a side of sweet potatoes, which were substantial and really good. Finally, we tried the Breakfast Roll ($15), which comes with a small side salad and is definitely worth the money. Delicious sandwich with scrambled eggs, avocado, and a slightly spicy tomato sauce. For drinks we shared a Match latte ($5), which was also really tasty. Will certainly return to Two Hands soon.
Food was very delicious and fresh. Sizable quantity as well. Got the chicken salad sandwich + pulled chicken salad. Nice outdoor seating area.
Picked up a brassicas salad for lunch and it was delicious! I added smoked salmon for extra protein and it was the perfect nutritious mid day meal. The staff were also really nice!!
Staff were very kind, and the feel of the restaurant was very fun and vibey. The food was delicious and the consistency of the acai bowl was unreal. Will have to go back!
OMFGGGGGG the portobello mushroom burger (added halloumi) Was literally so so so so so good. Wow. *I NEVER YELP REVIEW BUT THIS WAS FLAMES DAWG literally can't stop thinking about it

My wife came here this morning. She is five months pregnant. She walked in, saw an open table and asked if she could be seated. She was told there was a thirty minute wait. Immediately a couple walked in behind her and the host promptly seated them at the table. She was told she would be notified when her table was ready. Forty minutes later she came back because she hadn't gotten a notification and they had given away her table so she was forced to wait another twenty minutes. This is unacceptable!
No comment
The service is bad. Inattentive and forgetful staff. The food is very bland and expensive. Not worth your time or money.

So good! Everything is as contact free as possible (you scan a QR code for the menu) and they take your temperature and give you hand sanitizer as you come in. The food is also very delicious and the portions are a good size for the price. They are also kind enough to let joggers use their restroom! Very kind staff.

The Soho location of Two Hands has been one of our favorite Aussie brunch places (of the 8 or so in the neighborhood) so I was very excited when a new branch opened two blocks away from us. Went there for brunch this morning. Brightly lit yet cozy interior. The menu was more extensive than the one posted on the website (as of today, Feb 2). They had all the classics but also a veggie burger with pesto sauce, which turned out to be really good. Oat latte was also great. Service was friendly and attentive. They don't take reservations but they were not needed today. Might be soon as I can see the place become very popular.

This is the new favorite lunch place for my whole office. I've tried a lot of things on the menu, but the veggie burger is my favorite - I love it with no bun on the kale salad. The banana bread with espresso mascarpone is unreal too. Their matchas are amazing, and they have kombucha on tap. Everything is super consistent and easy. Keep it up, Two Hands!

Beautiful location and great staff but I'm sad to say that the quality and taste of the food at Two Hands has really gone downhill. The acai tasted awful and frozen and as you can see in the picture, there were barely any fruits. This bowl costs $14.
Cute and cosy environment with lovely servers. Many options for drinks and food with fast service!! Definitely recommend
Told a server we found a hair in the bacon: "well I actually didn't take your order but.. okay." Rude. Unfriendly. Negative experience all around. Nobody even apologized for the hair.
Fab Aussie cafe.  This location only a couple of weeks old, so no line!  Excellent food.  Great coffee.   Now on our favorite list for brunch!

Wow, what a great dining experience.   Our server and sommelier were well informed and helpful in selecting wine and our dishes.   High marks go to the chef on the Dover sole and the incredible lime vermouth sauce that accompanied the fish.  The dumplings were amazing as well.  We highly recommend this French cuisine restaurant.  Beautifully decormated as well.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Nice intimate setting inside the Wall St., Hotel The service was great. Started with the clams in the pastry shell sauce was very tasty. The duck with a peanut sauce was delicious . The lamb which they claimed was the signature dish was very chewy and a bit of a disappointment. The wines by the glass considering the restaurant were very reasonable and a great selection. The manager was kind enough to give us a bowl of fried rice on the house which was delicious. Not too pricey for a restaurant that's inside a hotel and will probably come back to try seafood dishes.

Everything about this restaurant was divine. A client hosted a private dinner and from the moment we stepped inside the Wall Street Hotel I was impressed. The decor is very modern and swanky. Everything we ate was sooo good. Our host was super attentive and always asking if we needed anything. I think it's expensive but my company paid the bill so I don't know for sure lol. I will for sure be back for drinks.
No comment
No comment

Delicious dinner & service.  Beautiful new brasserie in Fidi.  Exactly what the neighborhood needs.  Surprisingly busy on a Tuesday night.  Vibrant, energetic crowd that evening.  Perfect for an upscale dinner, yet also accessible enough to be a neighborhood gem.  I see us returning often.  The pork belly endive with egg was genius, the French onion dumplings were amazing.  Service was attentive, timely and friendly.  I look forward to exploring the rest of the menu.  Thanks to Ogun for taking care of us and to Phillip for stopping by to check-in.

Amazing food, drinks and service. Their desserts are craftsmanship. I've never had any foods with pearls lol. Great place for dates and fancy group dinners. Our booth was just the right size for our small group and it beautiful wallpaper and has a gorgeous monstera leaf chandelier.
No comment
No comment
No comment
Love everything about this restaurant. Food, decor and service was amazing. Mott was our bartender and  very attentive. My favorite dish out of what we ate was the ahi tuna spring roll.

As a neighborhood resident I am probably a little biased. But La Marchande is not just a neighborhood darling. I've not yet been to a modern French that's as elegantly and youthfully executed from entry to exit. The mushroom broth dumpling and duck salad alone are worth my repeat visit. The ambiance is chic, refined, without being all batard, truly an energy that feels appropriate for the corner of fidi that is somewhere only we know. I love the wine list and cocktails too. Menu design is exciting and you have to try really really to taste the butter. I love the menu and the experience. Food is 9/10.
No comment

The waiter Will...give him a raise! his customer service was top-tier, definitely added to the overall impression of the restaurant.  That type of service that creates referrals! Will, William, he's a keeper, promote him
No comment

Total shit show! We ordered a 2017 chateau neuf du pape wine, the sommelier brings us a 2019, argues with me what's on the menu, concedes and tells me they're basically the same. If you know wine and dine at established restaurants this would be a major red flag. The dinner... server goes on about how the lamb is their most popular dish, I order it, they forget to serve it with the sides they list with it on the menu, and then tell me that the chef was quickly preparing them. The table next to us, they dropped the drinks on the 2 of the women, who were beautifully dressed. The food is not great, service is mediocre, and the worst is the staff has no clue. It was embarrassing to be here.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Was craving Taiwanese breakfast so came here and did the 2 people $35 set. It included a radish cake, fan Tuan, scallion egg pancake and soy milk. I liked how the sweet soy milk wasn't too sweet and the savory one was very filling as well. The fantuan only had pork floss and youtiao, wasn't anything spectacular and the radish cake wasn't good. The scallion egg pancake was okay, I liked the dipping sauce but overall not very impressed by this spot!

I'm from Austin, TX and we don't have too many options for Taiwanese breakfast in the area, so I had to have some while in NYC. The restaurant is tiny, fits about 6-7 people. Luckily there was an empty table for two, as we came here on one of the coldest days of the year. We got the breakfast set for two. We both got sweet soy milk (hot), and it was perfect for the weather. The soy milk was sweetened just slightly and tasted fresh. The fan tuan came out next. My only gripe with it is that I wish it had more preserved veggies in it. Otherwise, the rice was perfectly sticky and chewy, and the you tiao added a nice crunchy texture. The radish cake was my favorite part of the set. I wanted more! The scallion pancake was also pretty good. I liked the spicy sauce that it came with. All in all, I think Ho Foods did Taiwanese breakfast justice.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
My fav was the soy milk, perfect for my taste palate. We also got the fan Tuan with pork floss and crepe. I think the set menu is more worth it and will definitely get that next time!
No comment

We got the hot half sweet soy milk, yo tiao, fan tuan, radish cake and scallion pancake with egg. Favorite was the fan tuan with the scallion pancake a little flat flavor wise. The menu is a lot smaller than I had anticipated (missing items from the previous menu) and prices a little high for what the food was. Overall underwhelming based on what we tried, but would satisfy the craving for Taiwanese breakfast in a pinch.
No comment
No comment
No comment

Visited this legendary Taiwanese beef noodle shop in Brooklyn right before it closed and it lived up to all the hype and then some! Their "red" beef noodle soup was quite flavorful and their Zha Jia Mien was delicious, as well as interestingly also being served with sliced cherry tomatoes. The scallion pancakes with egg wrapped within was also off the hook - hot and crispy, with a side of a peanut dipping sauce that was the bomb and also extremely good. You can also order Taiwanese beverages like Apple Sidra, soy milk and Taiwan Beer. A must-visit if you are ever in NYC and want to experience the best Taiwanese noodles!

column3: Central City, Salt Lake City, UT
column6: No comment

No comment
Pretty good, tasty, small chic place for a quick Taiwanese meal, my ABG told me it was semi authentic lol, nothing major major, but not bad either.
No comment
No comment

My girlfriend asked to eat Taiwanese breakfast and I'm very glad I found this spot. It's authentic and delicious, but not great during colder months since you have to dine outside. If you don't want to sit outside, they appeared to be very good with takeout orders, so I would opt for that option.

This is a decent Taiwanese breakfast place, but I will say it's a far cry from traditional Taiwanese breakfast. The radish cake and hot soy milk are fantastic, but the fan tuan doesn't have enough pickled veggies in it for my preference and a little too much youtiao. The scallion egg pancake is good and the whole breakfast set for 2 is a decent amount of food for the price. The space itself is a bit cramped but I don't mind it personally. Service is fine, nothing special and some of the staff seem to not want to be there.

A bit of disappointment from the food. Didn't have any expectations and came out being more disappointed. Services were great but the food was lacking. We got the combo, jiajiang noodle and the sesame noodle and almost everything came out overly salty. The appetizer, pickle, looked nice but tasted like eating salt. Once I put into my mouth, I had to stop and went to grab some rice. The noodle, both jiajiang and sesame, caught me off guard. Noodle stick together, the sauce didn't mix well into the noodle and still tasted salty. The only thing I like was their Lou ro rice. Nice egg presentation and the tiny strip size pork belly was very tasty with the rice.

Love this restaurant a lot! I often stop by for the pork rice and get a dessert from jell&chill next door(sadly it's closed) Nothing to complain about the food, authentic taste and nice service. But tbh it's overpriced. In general, highly recommended!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

This was my first Taiwanese breakfast. It's been over a week but I still think about it. I love tofu and just about anything soy. I've never had anything like the savory soy milk and it was delicious and addicting. I think it contained spicy sesame oil which was fragrant with scallion and very crispy yo tiao. My other favorite was the fan tuan which also had contrasting textures between the rice and yo tiao and the sweet/savory pork floss. I would come back for those two in addition to a sweet hot soy milk. They have a few seats inside as well as outside with overhead heaters. I plan to go back soon.
No comment
No comment
it's busy but it's worth the wait. beef noodle soup reminds me of home. a must go.  my sister says that the beef noodle soup is better than mine

So this place advertised 'grass-fed bone broth' and 'grass-fed beef' for a whopping price of $20 for a beef noodle soup. I don't eat red meat or gluten, but beef noodle soup is a classic Taiwanese dish, and I bought it for my dad. It was prepared pretty quickly, seating inside was limited, but I was trusting the quality. Overall seems like a decent spot I would order from again!
No comment

The real reason I come here - savory soy milk. I've been looking for this dish around New York and was delighted to find it here. It was flavor bomb in a bowl, sour from the vinegar, spicy from the hot oil, fresh from the green onions, and crunch savory fried dough. The sweet soy milk is good too but not as unique as the savory version. Other dishes I've tried are just okay. The beef noodle soup had oustanding soup base but the noodles were a little overcooked. The turnup cake was a bit bland and mushy, wouldn't recommend.
No comment

Ho Foods was good, but pricey for what it was. My friend and I ordered the scallion pancakes, beef noodle soup and the minced pork rice. The beef noodle soup was pretty good, but nothing special. We liked the scallion pancakes for the chewy texture. But the minced pork rice had a seasoning we couldn't quite place and decidedly did not like. Overall it was just an OK meal for $54.82. I was a bit disappointed because I'm Taiwanese and love Taiwanese food.
No comment

While it was a little bit on the pricier side m, everything was delicious. I ordered the set that comes with lu rou fan, wontons, cucumbers, and beef noodles, but if I had to do it again I would probably just order the beef noodles. The broth was fantastic! Probably the best that I've had in the city. It was super complex yet heartwarming at the same time. I also love how you can pick if you want thick or thin noodles
No comment
No comment

The menu's tiny, but nonetheless some of the items on there are worth getting. The chili wontons (with chicken) are very expensive, but we both liked them and wished that for $9, there would be more than just five pieces. The beef noodle soup was worth the price, as it was filling (one serving for both of us!) as well as tasty. We ordered extra spicy but for me it would be 6 on spice level. Good spot for a quick meal, or something longer, but the food's not cheap.
No comment
No comment

Went here for a solo dinner and was seated at the bar. The service was really great and the waitstaff were very nice and attentive. However, my review has three stars because the food was average. The broth was good but the portions were incredibly small and the meat could have been more moist (it was a bit dry and tough that day. While the broth was good, it lacked the complex flavor profile coming from the traditionally used spices. It was mostly salty so I wasn't able to appreciate everything else that went into it like star anise or cinnamon.
Tiny restaurant space with authentic Taiwanese food. Great service and love everything they serve. The pork rice is the best.
No comment
No comment
No comment
Limited menu but solid Taiwanese food. Love their soy milk and beef noodle soup. It's a small place so sometimes waiting for a table could be a little long. The staff is kind and patient.
No comment
No comment

A great place for noodles, and the broth is good, but sometimes it feels more oily. Still, it was cold and it warmed me right up and filled me. Would love to come back and try the Taiwanese breakfast!

I am so glad that a friend had brought me here. The Taiwanese beef noodle soup is an absolute star! The noodles were very good and the broth was amazing! The the pork belly bowl was to die for and I could eat that every day. The owner and his staff were so nice and you can tell they cared about their product and the quality of their food.
No comment
No comment
Delicious beef noodle soup, great service, and safe outdoor seating arrangement during Covid. I wouldn't hesitate to make a breakfast or dinner reservation on Resy.

Ho Foods is a small Taiwanese restaurant nestled in the East Village. We ordered the Chili Wontons to share which were just the right balance of spice and savory. Each of us stuck to the iconic Beef Noodle Soup for our main dish. The soup was simply perfect. The meat was tender and the broth was delectable. We will definitely be back soon.

I was a bit disappointed by their egg pancake, but I have to admit I was expecting a lot from this place. Overall it's not bad, actually there tofu with youtiao is really delicious and it is the only place you can find it at in the neighborhood, but the rest of the food was below the NYC standard I would say. So I wouldn't recommend or not recommend, it's just an average meal for an average occasion
No comment

The perfect noodle!!!! I love how chewy the noodles are and they pair so well with the beef. Seating is limited but they do have outdoor seating with heaters. Follow on insta @cravings.club for more food pictures!

Frustrating experience - they were understandably busy when we arrived, and we tried finding out what the wait looked like. We were asked to wait for a bit, and ended up waiting 20 minutes outside. We were then told it would be a 40 minute wait for a table. The wait is totally understandable, it's a busy morning, but it would have been much better to just tell us when we asked, rather than making us wait 20 minutes to be told that.

Tried to order from the site and it kept giving me errors so I ordered in person and was quoted 15-20 minutes. Ended up taking almost a full hour for me to get my food. Literally watched three parties sit down after I ordered and they ate and left before I got my food. After the first 20 mins I followed up and the host told me they were packing my order already only for it to take another 30-40 mins before I actually got my order. As for the food -- everything felt really oily and the you tiao in the fan Tuan was over fried to point that it was just crisp which made the whole thing overall rather dry. The egg in the lu rou fan was probably the highlight.
No comment
If you don't mind that it's not totally authentic (there's this intriguing orange peel flavor I personally love but others might not), the ru rou fan here is one of the best I've ever had.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Had the beef broth noodle, definitely a great bowl of richly flavored and fulfilling noodles that gives you a great feeling in a weekend lunch. The beef is very tender and perfectly cooked, the egg is very slightly overcooked but still make a great side. I got the wide noodles which I think is a good choice that allow more of the rich soup to linger on the noodles. The price is really quite high though, but given the quality it is worth it for an once in a while extravagance.

Got takeout from here on February 21. I've eaten here pre-COVID and the food was always great. You can never go wrong with beef noodles and pickled cucumbers. The meat is always tender and the broth is super rich. The acid from the cucumbers cuts through the richness and brightens up the whole meal.The small side of lu rou fan was yummy and with that superbly cooked egg, delicious. The set with all three was $30, a little pricey for the portion size but I'm a firm believer of quality over quantity and everything at Ho Foods is awesome so still definitely recommend

Great place to get your Taiwanese breakfast fix in. However be prepared to wait a while for dine in or just order to-go. I ordered the egg crepe roll, fan tuan and a hot sweet soy milk. The fan tuan was what I was looking the most forward to and it certainly was a delight to eat - the crunch from the Chinese donut was perfect and paired nicely with the pickled veggies and pork floss in the middle. Everything else that I had ordered were also delicious and still warm even though I was running late for pick up.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
Got the beef noodle soup. Super solid bowl of flavor and gave quite a bit of meat as well.

This is an authentic traditional Chinese brunch place. It's been so popular among Chinese friend circles. Always wanted to check it out and today we finally got the chance. We ordered almost all of the popular dishes/appetizers here and all of them taste great! My favorite is the Ru Rou rice bowl and the savory soy milk + pork floss. But it was really too hot so I couldn't finish all of them, especially the soy milk was hot too...
No comment

Delicious food and vibes! The space is small but they also offer outdoor seating (with heaters) they have different menus for lunch and dinner. We got a bunch of stuff from the dinner menu and everything was great (: also recommend their soy milk! Will come back to try their lunch menu!
No comment
Mediocre food, and high price, press the supply to increase the food price (with small portion and low efforts food)

The food is below average. You Tiao is double fried extremely unhealthy and also hard to chew. Marinated egg is obviously less marinated which tastes like nothing. Fan Tuan, which is my fav Chinese breakfast, is totally the worst among the food. A big disappointment

Wasn't super impressed by the food here. It doesn't taste similar to authentic breakfast foods I've had in Taiwan. They also don't have indoor seating and very limited outdoor patio seating so make a reservation if possible!
No comment
No comment
got their sesame noodles + egg togo, and while it was super yummy, it was pretty expensive for what it was
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Originally came upon Ho Foods a couple years ago, but the waits were insane. We were in New York recently, and decided to have 2nd brunch here because I love love love Taiwanese breakfast. We got there 11:30am on a Sunday and waited 20 minutes for 2 people. There's like 11 seats total. The sweet soy milk was great. Perfect texture, not too sweet. The you tiao is a bit oily and extra crispy since it's double fried but goes well dipping it in the sweet  soy milk. The Lu rou fan is normally at dinner but I think they serve it pretty consistently for brunch now. It's really good. Yes everything will be expensive for what it is, but consider the neighborhood you are in. Will definitely be back for dinner to try the beef noodle soup!!
No comment

Ho Foods is the only place in Manhattan that can satisfy that urge when I'm craving a Taiwanese breakfast. I've had almost everything on the menu and I have yet to be disappointed. The space is small though so not ideal to bring more than a part of 4. Also if you arrive too late in the day, many of the more popular items are often sold out. So my suggestion is come bright and early by yourself or with no more than a couple of friends!
No comment
No comment

Tried the wide noodles takeout with extra rich bone marrow and seasonal green veggies too: Same yumminess just a bit different in flavor. Notably the green vegetable tasted very fresh and crisp not your usual thrown-in cheap bok-choy. Will be back more often as much as I can :)
Beef noodle soup: that's all you need to know. Go and enjoy, maybe have a beer or some of the sides, sit outside and slurp up the goodness. Rich and delicious.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Stumbled upon this when the original place I wanted to go was closed, and it was THE BEST experience I've had in a long while. Had one of the best Taiwanese beef noodles and the beef just melts in your mouth. Turnip cake was wonderful and so was the scallion egg pancake. Sat in the outdoor seating area, service was great. Will definitely be coming back!
No comment
No comment

Tiny spot with a menu of a few select dishes. My friend and I shared the Ho foods classic red cooked (beef noodle soup with wide noodles) and Lu rou fan (pork belly). Everything was very tasty. Not sure I'd return again unless I was craving that exact soup, but it was good. 3.5 stars.

So happy to be able to order Taiwan breakfast for Sunday morning and delivered.  All the food are freshly made - hot soy milk, savoy sticky rice ball, egg scallion pancakes, radish cakes, and fried croutons.  All taste so authentic.  We feel very blessed and happy and are sharing this with all friends so they can enjoy this gem too.

This tiny hole in the wall only has 2 tables, but that definitely doesn't mean it should be overlooked. It took a little while from when we put our name in the list, but we were able to just walk around nearby. I'm often quite intimidated by large menus, so it was a pleasant surprise to see one with just one main dish on it: Taiwanese beef noodle soup. If a restaurant knows how to make something well, they should be applauded for focusing on that rather than trying to make tons of different fancy dishes. It was a cold night when we came here and the hot soup really hit the spot.

Yelp recommended this place to me, and I was drawn in by the food photos on its page. It's pretty easy to get to, about 10 minutes walk from the subway. It's a pretty tiny shop, and they've done an unbelievable job making use of the space - they have outdoor seating and several indoor tables as well a bar. We both got the beef noodle soup with wide noodles, and my boyfriend got the rich + spicy while I got the spicy. This was an absolutely phenomenal bowl of noodles! The richness and depth of flavor of the broth, the chewiness of the noodles, and the absence of fat chunks on the beef made this one of the best beef noodle soups I've had. It really reminded me of bowls I had in Beijing! They were also SO nice here. It is a little pricey (it ended up being $45 for both of us including tip, and we only got the noodle soup) but I don't regret it in the slightest!! Give this place a try!!
The beef noodle soup and radish cake were both good and decent, though not amazing. The soy milk was ok but tasted slightly diluted!? In any case, this place is a decent spot.

Got this recommendation from a friend and it did not disappoint. The authentic breakfast, beef noodle soup, and wonton were *amazing*. I cannot recommend enough. It can be a bit of a wait, so definitely get a reservation if you're looking to go during a busy time.

Came back on a Saturday around noon for the savory soy milk and was disappointed that it doesn't taste like the Taiwanese savory soy milk that I am accustomed to. I agree with other yelp reviewers that it is watery; I would describe it as having a high ratio of light chicken broth to curdled soy, whereas I'm used to the base being soy milk. I think the savory soy milk here is okay in terms of taste, just not the savory soy milk taste I am familiar with from visits to Taiwan growing up. Despite the subpar dish, we had a pleasant experience with the staff. Servers moved efficiently and politely in the busy, cramped shop. We wanted to eat-in but ended up changing to take-out after learning of a projected 35-40 min wait. Our take-out experience went well - we weren't shooed outside in the cold to wait, and received our order in the 20-25 min estimate with spoons and napkins included in the to-go paper bag.

Finally visited this place for breakfast in which the menu is quite different from lunch/dinner. Went in mid nov (actually rented Zipcar for this lol) I'm half Taiwanese so in my opinion, pretty decent food - just a tad pricy (well, it's nyc.. but hey this pretty close to what you can get!!). My favorites were the you tiao (fried cruller) and sweet soy drink (hot). The fried crueller was made to order, pipping hot, crispy and yet not greasy. Dip in the soy drink (how a local Taiwanese would eat) - Waahhhh life is good and felt transported to Taiwan. Perfect match like you might dip French fries to a frosty (Wendy's) or hot fudge Sundae (McD)? Anyway you can relate! The sweet soy drink was not too sweet / just nice and having it hot was warming while sitting outdoor. Note there aren't many tables (and no heat when I went) so go super early like when they open otherwise just wait a bit. When we got there, all tables just got taken so we put down our number and walked around and came back in 15-20mins. The waiter (young gentleman) was nice, fast and friendly. You have to order using their website so have your phone and payment ready but they will bring you out the food. Just make sure you put the table number (waiter can help you). For me, the fan Tuan is not the best I had (I think winson in williamsburg is better), the rice roll is too skinny and with the very crispy fried cruller just felt too crunchy and lack of soft chewy rice to balance it. Radish was a bit dense texture to my taste but not bad. Overall great and satisfying experience. Hope to come back another time soon one day.

We came her on a rainy night and the wait was very minimal, about 10 minutes. We sat at the bar and it was a little tight but acceptable. The service was great, very friendly and courteous. We had two servings of their noodles. One with their stock broth and wide noodles and the second with their regular thick noodles and rich and spicy extras. Both were flavorful but the added rich and spicy provided more depth and is the obvious way to experience their noodles if you can tolerate a little heat. We also tried all the appetizers offer that day (cucumbers, tofu, and pork over rice) and found them very underwhelming. If I had to come back, I would opt for just the noodles but even then I don't see it worth the wait, especially not at their prices and the reported 1+ hrs. In summary, pass on the appetizer and try the noodles if you can manage to get a seat with minimal wait.

We enjoyed a Taiwanese brunch at Ho Foods today.  A few things to know: (1) the space is super small (only a few tables) so you'll likely have to wait unless you happen to get there at the right time, (2) they do not serve their famous beef noodles on their breakfast menu.  I enjoyed their Egg Bing and Fan Tuan.
Speaking as a Taiwanese, this was one of the most authentic bowl of Taiwanese beef noodle soup I have ever had in New York! It's a tiny bit pricey, but totally worth it.

How does one describe need that simply melts in your mouth? Tender like medium rare steak with the rich burst of juicy flavor. Add spice or don't either way the broth is the warmest hug you've ever known. Pricey but every penny is worth it!!! Tofu was delicious but not as life changing.

5-stars for breakfast, 4-stars for dinner. While Ho Foods is famous for their beef noodle soup, I actually preferred their breakfast menu! I recently traveled to Taiwan and came back craving all sorts of Taiwanese food - especially breakfast items like fresh soy milk and fan tuan. It's hard to find these things in Manhattan but Ho Foods does them and does them well.

Finally got to try this place!  The 滷肉飯 (Lu roh fan) is the best I've had in the city. So yummy and the texture is like the ones we have at home. As for the beef noodle soup doesn't have enough flavor or depth. The noodle is perfectly cooked and the meat is good quality and well cooked. The meat strangely in a big cut (instead of traditional chunks). I'd go there for the rice!

I've always wanted to go this place and I finally did! Their food was just so good. The staffs were amazing and the food was excellent. I wish I live in the hood so that I can enjoy this more often. :-(

Delicious and savory Taiwanese breakfast foods. The soy milk was sour and spicy and salty and came topped with green onions and a sort of pork crouton. The three dishes on the breakfast menu (egg bing, turnip cake, and fan tuan) were solid.
This is the best Taiwanese restaurant we have had in US , consider we were from Taiwan and pretty picky. Everything is authentic and masterly prepared.

Authentic Taiwanese food at great price and quality.  I don't know another place on the East coast that gets it soo right! Richard is the best!

HO MAN this place is so good. I first heard of this spot through the feature on First We Feast, and I have been meaning to come since then. It literally only has one thing on the main entree menu - the Taiwanese noodle soup - with a few different add ons. This is the most pure form of beef noodle soup with its three components - good noodles, good broth, and GREAT BEEF. The beef is the best I have had ever. The wait is about 25 - 30 minutes so definitely plan your visit and leave the wait time in!

Delicious  it's my first time trying Taiwanese food in Manhattan! I love the flat noodles and the tofu side dishes along with the rice. I would definitely come back again. There's a restroom at the back even though it's a small place with not so many seats or tables. We didn't have to wait at all and I don't know if we would be this lucky next time.

This is legit, authentic Taiwanese food. The lu rou fan (pork belly over rice) tastes much like the lu rou fan I get in Taiwan at Du Shiao Yuen and some night markets. The meat to rice ratio is good, it all melts in your mouth without feeling overly oily. The niou rou mien (beef noodle soup) was yummy too. I enjoyed the broth more with the added spicy option, very flavorful. I personally prefer the round noodles over the flat noodles. This place only seats up to ~11 people (some counter seating and some small tables), but we arrived at 4:45 pm and were seated in the first round. I've been trying to find good Taiwanese food in NYC for a while now, and this is the best I've had, closest to actual Taiwanese eats. Ho Foods gets high accolades from this Taiwanese American girl. I'm going to bring my parents (who grew up in Taiwan) here - they'll love it.

Went for breakfast on Sunday around 11:30. Got a seat at the bar. Music was good, all Spanish, made me want to dance. The soy drink was good I had, warming on a cold day. The turnip cake was good, I liked the other thing I had more tho, purple rice wrapped around a Taiwanese doughnut. Tasty. I'll come back for the beef noodle soup in the evening. The waitress was so friendly and helpful. Thanks Kim! Great service.

I was super excited to try this new taiwanese restaurant in east village. I waited for an hour since the restaurant is so small. Because it's soft opening, they only serves the main noodle soup, marinated cucumber, and soft tofu. You can add up more flavors if you like rich & spicy, and they also have extra meat & other sides like Pho. The soup was not flavorful at first, but once I put all of the pickled green it became perfect. I would give five stars but the side order of tendon was just sad. It was $2.50 add on and they gave me thin two slices of tendon LOL honestly that's a joke. My suggestion is mark the price higher and give people plenty to eat. Love the little family restaurant vibe :) I cant wait to try their other dishes after the soft opening.

Big fan of Ho Foods. You can always opt for the quick and dirty beef noodle soups in Chinatown, but you can't find the same quality that you'll be able to enjoy at Ho Foods. The noodles, beef, and ingredients taste very fresh here. Love the pickles/mustard that come as a side. It's really small, so on weekends, there can be a wait. Price point I'd say is slightly higher that expected, but worth it.

I lift. Please send noods. Ho Foods is a Taiwanese beef noodle soup spot currently in their soft opening (6-10pm). Their menu is simple: "red cooked" beef noodle soup with 24 hour bone and marrow broth, grass fed beef shanks, and your choice of thick of wide noods. Check it out! Their owner, Rich, who also happens to share the same name as me, is really friendly and will answer any questions you may have. Be prepared for a 10-20 min wait as the shop is quite small with three tables and a counter. It's unfair to compare this spot to the ones in Taiwan however so temper those expectations. I wish them lots of luck and success!

Just came here for dinner. There's only one main dish on the menu - red braised beef noodles. It was really delicious. I like when restaurants offer simple choices but get them right! Keep the authenticity and keep up the good work!

Staff was very friendly and breakfast menu was short and sweet. We ordered the soy milk & cruller, egg bing, and fan tuan. The food was really good and thought it was comparable to the food I had in Taiwan! The place only had about 10 seats and we only waited 30 minutes around noon. Wish there was a heater in the place but I think it is worth coming for brunch. I will definitely be back for dinner

If you like ramen then you need to try Taiwanese beef noodle soup (and the tons of other asian noodle soups for that matter). It is so delicious and addicting. It's like crack in savory form and not bad for your health. I'm so glad to see other forms of noodle soups gaining traction. This place is nice and clean with great owners.

My husband and I came here a bit earlier than it opened there were already a line. The place is pretty small. We were able to get in to the first round of customer to be served. The food came pretty fast. The seasoning seems a bit light. It doesn't taste bad but it is definitely not comparable to beef noodle soup in Taiwan. But it's a good place to visit if you are craving a Taiwanese beef noodle soup.

Dining in the age of covid isn't always easy. Outdoor dining rained us out, but we took our food home. An excellent classic take on Taiwanese beef noodle soup. I prefer and suggest the wide noodles (more traditional) and don't usually add anything to the soup though they have options for bok Choy etc. The broth is excellent, the noodles are SO GOOD!, the meat comes right off the bone. Small modern space so I wouldn't plan on walking in with 2+ and expecting to sit immediately. I stopped in alone the other night and there was a 30 minute wait. The cucumber appetizer is good but not the best I've had, very simple, just cucumber and vinegar. Also, it says No delivery but I believe UberEATS does.
Soso good, a caring staff, incredible sake, and the beef noodle soup reminded me of my time in Taiwan. 14/10 would recommend to a friend
The beef noodle soup was souperb. 24 hours broth packed with flavor and you can control how rich or spicy you want your broth to be. It's a small place with a few seating, but worth the wait.

The store is extremely tiny, would suggest not to get there with a party of more than 4.  The waiting is fine, since they would message you once the table is ready.  There is only one noodle choice on the menu.  The whole beef noodle soup is delicious.  Pretty decent when comparing where i have had in Taiwan.  Remember to add the beef tendon to make the noodles perfect.  Both flat and round noodles are nice.  I tried both and I love them.  Last but not least, order the tofu for appetizer.

The BEST beef noodle soup I've ever had! Ho Foods as perfected it, the beef melts in your mouth, the 24hr broth is rich and delicious and the noodles a perfect texture. Their appetizers are all really good too. I need to come back to try the breakfast too!

Food was decent - I got the beef noodle soup set, which I thought was good value. The ru rou fan was good, but the beef noodle soup wasn't very flavorful and just tasted salty so wasn't very impressed. The set also came with cucumbers and soy milk. If I came back, I wouldn't get that set again.

Beef noodle soup was decent -- didn't understand all the hype surrounding this place though. For a restaurant that specializes in one entree only, I expected more. My friend and I both ordered the wide noodles without any add-ins (perhaps that was our mistake) and while she loved the heartiness, I felt the dish could use a little more flavor. And more salt! It probably didn't help that I don't particularly like cilantro, and the bowl was filled with it. Noodle texture was great though! However, at nearly $20 per person, I think there is some room for improvement.

Simply delightful and delicious. This spot only seats 10... worth the wait. 1 main course with 4 add on options and 4 side dishes to choose from. We had it all and not one item disappointed. The owner is gracious and attentive... chatted with us while we waited outside for a table. The waitstaff... all non-Taiwanese, were as passionate and knowledgeable of the food ingredients as the owner was. The beverage selection, of which we tried all of, were perfect pairings for the array of flavors and aromas this place produces. Would've bought a t-shirt or a hat if they sold them. Kudos! Will return!

we got taiwanese breakfast for takeout and chose the breakfast spread - dan bing, fan tuan, salty soymilk, and radish cake. everything was good, albeit on the oily side (these are fried foods after all). the orange spicy sauce was surprisingly good! I did find the salty soymilk a bit flat in flavor - it curdles as expected, but I am used to the addition of eg dried shrimp, pickled mustard root etc. we opted to not do outdoor dining when we looked at their setup, which is not socially distanced at all. space is limited in the east village, I guess. the handoff was friendly though, and I appreciate how you have to opt in for utensils and can avoid accumulating disposables.

My impression about @hofoodsnyc is that the beef noodle soup encapsules all the goodness in the bowl with a minimalistic presentation, almost like Art. What makes a good bowl are essentially the quality of the beef, the richness of the soup, and the freshness of the hand pull noodles. I also loved the humble shop with only three tables and a small bar counter which took away the commercial, restaurant-esque feeling and replaced it with an intimate and personal environment as if you are dinning at a friends place. lastly, I love supporting a Taiwanese business! Especially knowing that I'm only two degrees separated from the chef/owner!
Greatest service by a most excellent host who's remarkable memory for names made my girlfriend, Alice, feel at home.

Only one main entree menu item but that's all they need with the food being that good. The beef noodle soup was delicious, and comes as a generous portion! This Taiwanese classic certainly won't disappoint and is perfect to warm up during a cold winter day!! Would highly recommend coming here to eat!
This is the most authentic Taiwanese beef noodle I have ever had in NYC. Definitely worth a try!

I love the noodles! No matter what is the taste of Taiwan noodles but the food tastes good! Everyone in the restaurant is friendly. I tried both dinner menu and breakfast menu. No disappointed! Will return soon! A friendly tip, personally do not like the savory soy milk. Wasn't because of the chef makes it bad. It's because in my mind soy milk should be sweet and this one cooks like Tofu soup but Tofu soup is better. Anyways this is how a Taiwan style salty soy milk should taste like.

I discovered this place by a recommendation from a friend and being a noodles person I knew I had to try it! We were greeted by someone who I believe was the owner and was very friendly. It was packed when we came but we were about to give him our name and phone number so they can text us when a space is available. My first impression of the restaurant was the obvious; it's very tiny! There is 1 table for a group, 2 for couples and some high tables for individuals. The menu right now is very limited but I'm very excited to see what new dishes they made add to the menu. For the appetizer, you must try the tofu with century egg! Some people might be hesitant to try the century egg but it is delicious! I thought it was an excellent combination with the soft tofu. The noodles were delicious! The broth was everything. Fresh and full of flavor! The beef was also delicious and nicely sliced. Portions was just right. Also, you can pay with Apple Pay!

Tried on first day of opening, gave side dishes as a complimentary with the beef noodle soup. The wait is too long (approx 2 hour) we came at 6:30pm. They open at 6:00pm. Total 10 seats. Owner and staffs are pretty friendly.

If you're in the mood for delicious Taiwanese beef noodle soup, there is only one place to go in NYC...Ho Foods! You can sense the love in every delicious dish that Chef Rich creates.  And The Taiwanese breakfast menu is .

The beef noodle soup was quite authentic , can tell ingredients were fresh , also the minced pork rice was good, small place so probably be the best to go before they open or off meal times . It's very cozy environment. Ask for the prune juice . Was happy to find this place
No comment

One of the top restaurants on our NYC food bucket list was Ho Foods NYC because we LOVE Taiwanese food!!  Yes, we are 台灣人 so we always feel so warm and fuzzy inside when we eat some bommmb Taiwanese food!  We went on a Saturday morning for their breakfast and LET ME TELL YOU. We were very well prepared and showed up 15 minutes before it opened since we knew the line gets super long! You must go before it opens in order to beat the crowd!  We highly highly suggest the Egg Bing (蛋餅), which is an egg pancake with pork sung and green onions in it  It was definitely our favorite dish because we grew up picking it up from the streets of Taiwanese on the go! Always get us feeling nostalgic about our childhood  Falling not far behind from the Egg Bing is the Fan Tuan (飯糰), which is like , but we like to get it with purple sticky rice! It's got Chinese donut, which is called yiu tiao (油條) in it along with pork sung and pickled radish  The yiu tiao at Ho Foods was ESPECIALLY crispy, which makes it SO MUCH BETTER!!!! Let me know if you've tried it! We need to go back for dinner next time to eat their famous beef noodle soup (牛肉麵)!

This place is small, fun, and delicious! We were seated in about 10 minutes for breakfast. We had most of the breakfast items and they were great!  The savory soy milk was the best--salty and crunchy and with a kick of vinegar. The soy milk, fan tuan, and turnip cakes were all very good too. Definitely will be coming back here to check out the dinner too.

Best breakfast in the East Village! We always get the entire brunch menu and only regret not getting more! The savory soy milk with fried cruller bits, pork floss, and black vinegar might be the tastiest thing to ever hit NY. Do it! Order it! Love it!

Second time here which will also be the last time. Is the owner too greedy or something? The portion of the food got way less than the 1st time( wasn't a good experience either) which is why I wanted to give it a second chance. TBH, the soup taste like water down soy sauce with chili oil. Raku next door has better beef noodle soup.

Ho foods is a restaurant that I feel lucky to have found! I always say that it's my wintertime staple, but even in 80% humidity and 90 degree NYC summers, I will would walk blocks and blocks for their traditional beef noodle soup (make it spicy!). The owner Richard and his incredibly kind and welcoming staff make each trip memorable. I literally recommend this to anyone - people visiting for the first time or people who have lived here there whole lives! I love Ho!
No comment

I appreciate the care that they put into making the food, but the actual taste was not amazing. I thought the broth was bland and very oily, especially with spice added. My friend got it without spice, and there was still a lot of oil. The best part of the bowl was the texture of the homemade wide noodles and the beef, but everything else didn't really feel worth it.

If you want pure, clean, homemade kitchen style with only the best ingredients for beef noodle soup, then you better get here at 5pm or 9pm if you don't want to wait in line. Their menu is small but that's why everything is so good. Rich the owner is also super nice and makes the soup from the soul.

MUST TRY. This place truly reminds me of being back in Taiwan and eating my favorite comfort dish. I got the wide noodles with spicy addition. The tofu is also a huge hit and I highly recommend! The location only holds 3-4 tables but if you come at an off time, the wait isn't too bad. Can't wait to go back again! Chef Richard Ho was also super nice and told us a little bit about what it was like to open up the restaurant as welll as his journey in the food industry.

The breakfast was super trash and definitely not worth the food poisoning. If you have had real taiwanese food before, don't bother coming here for breakfast. They can't even get the sauce right for an simple egg pancake. There wasn't a single Taiwanese person in the kitchen and it shows. I truly hope their beef noodle soup is better because this place is an insult to Taiwanese cuisine.

This is going to be your new "spot"... currently top of my list of favorite nooks in NYC. Incredible beef noodle soup- always on point. The pickled sides add a whole range of flavor. Ho Foods is something you have to experience... bring a friend or two and enjoy a delicious hot meal, cozy environment and super friendly staff.
No comment

Amazing food. We went there early, the first guests on a weekday. The turnip cake is ok but the beef noodle soup is probably the best I have eaten sofar. Highly recommended. Go early since it it's really small and only fits 8 people.

Upon a Saturday evening, my friend and I decided to give this beef noodle soup place a try. Growing up eating beef noodle soup as one of my favorite dishes, I had heard great things about this place and the authenticity of the restaurant. I came during their soft opening and came and waited 30 minutes before the actual opening of the restaurant. The whole restaurant seats no more than 16 people, and having JUST missed the cut off for the first wave of people to be seated, we ended up waiting in the cold (we came in February) for 1.5 hours to be seated. We ordered the tofu appetizer and the rich beef noodle soup. The food came up relatively quickly, and service was really good (server/cofounder was aware of the wait and trying to minimize/effectively get people seated and fed ASAP) however the quality of the beef noodle soup was only mediocre. I didn't think the broth was that flavorful (kinda bland) and the beef wasn't the melt in your mouth goodness that I'm familiar with at home. Overall, didn't think it was worth the 1.5 hour wait and unfortunately probably won't be coming back.
authentic Taiwanese food. definitely a go to place for beef noodle soup!!! the staff is friendly as well!!!

I've been meaning to come here since I'm a big noodle person and I saw all the pictures on social media. I was greeted by the host/ owner when I arrived. He was very polite and took my name and number while I waited for a the next seat. The interior is small but very minimalistic in a good way. The server was extremely friendly taking care of and needs I had before, during and after my meal. I ordered the beef noodle soup with wide noodles. The noodle soup is on the small side but the quality is very premium. The broth was rich and had layers of flavor. The noodles had a perfect bite to it which I never have at asian noodle places. The beef was extremely tender and soft. Although I personally prefer a fattier beef but I can see they were trying to keep it traditional to the Taiwanese roots. Overall I enjoyed my meal and loved the great service. Will definitely be coming back with my girlfriend so she can try.
No comment

We waited about an hour for this place because there are only 10 seats in the restaurant. It was definitely worth the wait because this is the closest beef noodle to what I have had in Taiwan. The noodles are very chewy, and the spicy broth is very flavorful. We also tried the pork belly rice and it was on point too. It is pretty expensive for beef noodle soup, but it's worth trying once.

I like the beef and noodles very much, however, the soup is not rich enough. Given the price (14.5/bowl), I suppose the soup is ready to be served and rich enough. However, you need to add 1 or 2 bucks to make it "more rich", I think it is not reasonable.

Ho Foods is a straightforward hole-in-the-wall beef noodle soup restaurant with a very cool atmosphere. Perfect for dates. Note that there is very limited seating (15 people max?) so you want to get there earlier

Tried Ho Foods for the first time last night with my kids. This place served a delicious, authentic Taiwanese meal - We tried the tofu, pickled cucumbers, pork belly over rice, and the beef noodle soup (of course!) - My wife felt like she was having a home-cooked meal, her version of soul food, taking her back to when she lived in Taiwan. The Taiwanese beer topped it off perfectly. We will definitely be back!

Winner, winner chicken dinner!  Ho Foods is the real deal Holyfield people.  If you say anything like "it's better in Taiwan", you should get an Evander hook to the head.  We're in NYC peeps, not Taiwan (so the prices are going to reflect that), but that said, what Chef Ho has managed to accomplish here in America is nothing short of a miracle.  He has created Taiwan in the East Village.  From the small, cozy confines, to the family style service, to the - MOST IMPORTANTLY - beef noodle soup, this joint is every bit worth the reviews you're reading and buzz you're vibin'.  Slurp worthy succulent soup, melt in your mouth high quality beef, and thick or wide choice of noodles, the bowls take you right back to TWN even if you can't be there.  Plus, minced pork rice on the side?  Washed down with an ice cold Taiwan Beer?  It's worth the wait, gang, trust the process.
No comment

This place puts Taiwanese cuisine in the spotlight, and couldn't have picked a more noteworthy dish that symbolizes Taiwanese cuisine. Similar to beef noodle shops in Taiwan, this place specializes on the one item and executes it very well. The beef noodle soup is the only main entree on the menu, and you can customize it by adding spice or tendon, or having round or wide noodles. The meat was cooked perfectly: not chewy and melts in your mouth. The noodles cooked al dente. The soup was rich and flavorful. The service was quick and hospitable. I took a lu you fan (listed as an appetizer) to go, and it tasted just like how a Taiwanese household would make it. Highly recommend to anyone wanting a crash course in Taiwanese cuisine. Go early for dinner service!

Bomb ass taiwanese food. It's small and doesn't seat many people, but it's worth the wait. Put your name down go have a beer and come back hungry! They have like five things on the menu... Order all of them.
No comment
No comment

Got the extra thick noodles with tendon.  It's the closest to authentic Taiwanese beef noodle soup I've had in the city.  Also got both the appetizers, simple by delicious. The people there are great as well. Highly recommend!
No comment
I loved that there are only a few things on the menu, and that they had Taiwanese beer. Cute and small. Beef soup was excellent. Chef and server were so friendly
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
Tried the breakfast menu. Way Overpriced. Very small portion.  Place is tiny. Taste is just mediocre.

The East Village is tough to stand out as an Asian noodle restaurant, but Ho Foods is a star. The broth hits your pallet and doesn't let go - it's warm, fragrant, delicious, and reminds me of my Asian roots. I'm definitely coming back for me. Ho Foods - keep it up!!

Visited earlier this week to try the thick noodles, and decided I prefer them to the wide noodles. Seriously, Ho Foods is so good that while I was eating I started looking up rental prices for the walk-up above it on StreetEasy.
Maybe they had an off day or my expectations were too high, but this is definition of mediocre
Very Taiwanese food. The cozy and clean, stylish layout also adds flavor into the experience.
No comment
One of the best bowls of beef noodle soup outside of Taiwan! The staff was extremely kind and welcoming

Best Taiwanese beef noodle soup in NYC in a cute cozy space. The staff is very attentive and friendly. I would definitely go back! I wished there was more of my favorite Taiwanese dishes on the menu. :)

Personally, I live a few blocks away from this place, so I have access to it a lot, this is the kind of place that I can pop in for dinner, or a great place to go on a date. I will say, the menu is not large, but their beef noodles are very good. I also thoroughly enjoy the cucumbers as an appetizer. It has a very homey vibe.

Overpriced and overhyped for what it is. Noddles and soup are great, but the beef is disappointing. The amount per serving is not enough for men. The cucumber is definitely not worth.  It tastes exactly like 醬瓜, which we eat with congee. So it makes no sense this dish being an appetizer in the menu with salty beef noddle soup. Overall 3.5 .
Streamlined menu. Only one main dish--Taiwanese beef noodle soup--and they do it exceptionally well. I got extra flavor and spice and loved it. Be prepared to wait for a table.

This cute hole in the wall restaurant only has 1 entree on its menu - and it absolutely nails it! The beef noodle soup is really great - filling, flavorful, and the meat is really tender. I also really like the one photo on the wall - very authentic and meaningful. The place is a little small so seating is limited, but the wait was not more 10 minutes on a Sunday night. I would recommend it to a friend and come again!
No comment

I'm no niu rou mian expert by any means, but this spot is killer. It's hong shao style. The thick noodles are spot on, the broth is light and flavorful (which I happen to love), and they have Gold Medal Taiwan Beer, which is the perfect complement. Will return.
No comment

Came here on a rainy weekday evening for their soft opening. The space is tiny and the wait was surprisingly long. Toward the end of a 80 minutes we almost walked away due to the wait, but boy am I glad we stayed. I had the spicy bowl with the think noodles and it was easily the best bowl of Taiwanese Beef Noodle soup I've had. Hopefully they figure out a more efficient setup because I would love to come back.

The beef noodles tasted good. But I have to say it's a bit pricy base on the food amount. I didn't feel full even I'm just a woman who has little appetite. The tofu is so small and costs me 8 dollars. Might be the worst choice I've been ever made. The store is small and crowded. Might not go again.
No comment

Been here twice now and have had 3 bowls. It's definitely the best taiwanese hong shao niu rou mian I've had stateside. Had just returned from Taipei a month before and was craving Taiwanese beef noodle soup and it certainly hit the spot. The space is small so the waits can be a bit longer than usual for a noodle spot but no worse (maybe better) than Ippudo when it was more popular. The soft tofu and pickled mustard greens (suan cai) were also really good as well. If you want a "lighter" take, order the regular. If you want a more lip smacking bowl, get the extra rich and spicy (maybe not for your 2nd bowl if you're still hungry). Will certainly be back and will bring friends.

I don't write reviews very often because it always feels like too much effort. Ho Foods totally felt like it deserved a review. The place is tiny- three small tables and a counter that seats four people. That doesn't subtract from the experience- in fact, it adds to the atmosphere that feels homey. The staff was welcoming and very knowledgeable. We ordered all the side dishes (sans the turnip cake- that's for next time). The cucumber dish was just right and felt homemade. The tofu was great too (fair warning, it is a little salty). My favorite side dish was the lu rou fan. This is actually one of my favorite comfort foods, and Ho Foods nailed it. Most lu rou fans that I've had are full of sweet soy sauce. This one was less so, with a subtler but extremely satisfying taste. The pork is fatty in the best way, and it coats your mouth. I look forward to getting it as takeout. We got the spicy beef noodle soup with wide noodles. It was authentically spicy and the noodles were made perfectly. Beef noodle soup noodles should be just the right amount of chewy- and Ho Foods aced that. Our table also got a taste of the mi jiang- a sweet peanut rice milk that's served for breakfast. It was one of the best things I've had in a while. This is such a fun and quality place to go eat. It deserves all the good press and hype it's been getting. I can't wait to come back soon.

This beef noodle soup is so good I think about it all the time. If I didn't live so far away I'd be having this at least once a week. The Lo Rou Fan is a freaking revelation too. Man, I need to go back this week.

I am a huge fan of restaurants like these. Have a tiny menu with literally a handful of dishes and make them perfect! This joint is small with one entree and 3 dishes. We ordered their entire menu and had their plum tea. It was perfect. Especially loved their tofu side. Had to order another one to end the meal. Great customer service by Christian. Will definitely be back.

Was craving taiwanese beef noodle soup and this place hit the spot exactly. I grew up eating this and it's such a homey comfort food for me. They do it authentically for sure. So far it's just this on the menu for lunch so hopefully they expand soon.

The breakfast menu is all of my favorite Taiwanese street foods!  The place is tiny but accommodated our large group.  There was a looong wait but fortunately there was coffee shops all around the hang out in.  I do wish the turnip cake had some bits of sausage or turnip, but it's quite flavorful as it is, so it wasn't so bad.
Owner and staff were super friendly and nice. Unfortunately the beef noodle soup lacked flavor and substance compared to what you actually get in the motherland.
I come here all the time and it never disappoints! I get the thin noodles, but you really can't go wrong. Pro tip: get the smoked plum juice--it is delicious and unlike anything I've ever tasted.

came here on a cold day with the hubs hoping for something delicious and comforting and we were not disappointed. we got there around 5:30pm on a saturday and were greeted by richard who told us the wait would be about 15minutes (they take your number down and will text if the wait is longer and you want to walk around). we were handed menus while we were waiting and by the time we decided what to order, our table was ready. the noodles were perfectly chewy, beef deliciously tender, and broth authentically taiwanese. throughout the dinner, i really appreciated richard personally welcoming and thanking all his patrons. went to big gay ice cream across the street afterwards for dessert-- was a great evening!
Small cozy space with delicious food. Tried their noodle soup, pork belly rice dish, cucumber salad--all tasted great. Owner and server were very friendly.

We had the Taiwanese breakfast now being served on weekends.  The options are limited but delicious. We had the radish cake, egg bing, rice roll and sweet soy milk. The couple at the next table were from Taiwan and vouched for the authenticity. I look forward to trying the beef noodle soup when I return.

Only one item on their menu. The noodles taste fresh but the broth was lacking in flavor. Service here is great. It's a small restaurant so large groups will be hard to accommodate. However I would much rather prefer Vietnamese  Pho over their beef noodle soup
Ordered the entire menu and every single dish was a banger. In particular, the noodles and soft tofu were eye openers. Great service completed a perfect meal. 11/10 will be back
Good foods (at least not Americanized).  Looking forward to their growth in their menu

they specialize in taiwanese beef noodle soup yet of the three nyc places i've had it in, this was the worst and most expensive. It still wasn't bad though, i finished it, I just won't be back next time i have a craving. I think the yelp rating is super inflated because the service is really nice, i know my waiter was. I paid extra to get it "rich" which is kinda lame also because it's not like it was overwhelming in flavor and your soup should be rich to begin with. If you live in the east village that's one thing, but really, if you're looking for good taiwanese beef noodle soup you can do a lot better than this and get it much cheaper.

Pretty authentic joint, but overpriced. Extra spicy costs an extra $3, which is a rip off and makes no sense. They only have Taiwanese beef noodles as the main course on their menu. I would recommend getting the wide noodles and extra pickled cabbage. They also have Taiwanese beers.

The best bowl of noodles I've had in NYC to date. The broth is rich and savory, and the noodles are perfectly chewy. Don't scoff at the price point - the quality is above and beyond worth the price tag. Will be returning many times in the future.

i'm taiwanese, grew up eating this in taichung and can tell you this place is the real deal. this is only place in new york that gets beef noodles right. expect a long wait if you go during prime time.

awesome taiwanese beef noodle. finally a place that tastes like the stuff ive had in taipei. i love the pickled veggies that come w it as it really enhances the broth. wait for a table is way too long though at a 14 table tiny noodle place. it definately needs to expand or do take out to accomodate the demand.

My First time to try Dumplings in Thai taste with 4 kinds of dipping sauce  food is so good and reasonable price . Nice decoration good to try when you visit this area . good food and good service staff is very nice and friendly. Must try !!
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Fun tiny dumpling spot on St. Marks, we sat at a little table and were handed a couple of menus. I loved the spicy chili oil and sweet soy sauce on the table. These came out hot and YUMMY and it's a good spot for a quick, casual & filling meal.
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment
No comment

Although the interior of the restaurant was small, it still had a great vibe. The staff was extremely friendly and patient with us as we were figuring out what we wanted to order. The food had to be transported home about 15 blocks, and it was still warm when we got there. The fried chicken dumplings were still crispy and were very flavorful. The chicken dumplings with soup noodles were also extremely flavorful. The meat concoction within the dumplings however was a little sweet, which might be a deterrent for some people. All around a great experience!
No comment
