Get a seat at the bar, you'll get better service and conversation with the bartender should you eat alone

Came here for breakfast before work, definitely delicious and top notch service! I had the uovo modenese, the layers of flavors were undeniable but the portions are princess size...especially for the $19 price tag!  Come here for innovative breakfast/brunch, but make sure to order a few side pastries if you're a big eater!!

Even by NYC standards it's pricey for very small portions. Most of the food was good, the blue crab crostini and Lumache were delicious. The main drawback was the hospitality, the hostesses (there were 3 of them for some reason) were unprofessional and rude for some reason, maybe they didn't get the call back for that great commercial they wanted. Our server was also a bit off, I heard him arguing with the manager about hing to serve people outside. The food is very good so probably just needs better management and some retraining of staff.
Truly amazing place. Excellent service. The best food ever. I always go back.

I missed out on the mobbed bar scene because I arrived precisely on time for my reservation, and my party was complete.  The restaurant was a bit noisy and tightly packed, but the delicious wines caused those irritants to fade into the background.  At my excellent server's recommendation, I tried both the Greco di Tufo, a full-bodied white with hints of tropical fruits and the Valle dell'Acate Cerasuolo di Vittora, a light and lovely blend of Nero d'Avola with my beloved Il Frappato grape.  For appetizer, I had to try the sheep's milk ricotta, and it lived up to its hype--rich, creamy goodness accompanied by perfectly charred grilled bread.  The lemon and rosemary focaccia that came gratis was also very good.  I was a little less impressed with my entree, the orecchiette with homemade duck sausage and broccoli rabe, which had a nice spice to it but was a tad overcooked and could have used more sauce.  One other issue I encountered was a lack of vegetarian choices.  Although the menu online featured an artichoke ravioli, it was missing from the menu presented the night I dined, and all pasta entrees contained at least one kind of meat. I was too carbo-loaded to have room for dessert, but some of the choices looked excellent.  Service was superb, with prompt water refills, wine tastings, and indulgence of my party's many questions about the menu.

After hearing all the hype about Locanda, I decided to come here for a bday celebration and brave the wait time for a dinner spot at the bar.  They weren't kidding about the long wait (around 1.5 hours on a Tues night) but the bar was so fun and lively.  The cocktails are yummy (I especially like the Sgroppino primavera!).  For dinner we had the lamb sliders, sheep's milk ricotta, blue crab crostini, papardelle with lamb bolognese,  and the orecchiette with duck sausage .  All was very good, the ricotta was light and heavenly and the lamb sliders were savory (although only 2 per serving).  However, the winner of the  night was the tripe alla parmigiana....OMG.  Tripe in a tomato-based stew filled with carrots and basil topped off with organic farm egg; the tripe texture went great with the stew.  I could eat like a dozen bowls of this dish.  The bar service was great overall and ended the night with complimentary glasses of champagne; after all this how can one not have a good time at Locanda Verde?
Lamb sliders, crab crostini and beet salad appetizers were all terrific! My husband enjoyed his brancini and my lamb bolognese was fantastic. All in all, a great dining experience.

Get the pasta! I think the rest of the menu is good but this restaurant really shines with the pasta dishes. The brunch menu is also good but really the dinner pasta dishes are the best they have. The space is also the most gorgeous ever - the private room is also so pretty.
If you're pondering to eat here or not, it's worth the visit.  Ambiance is trendy grownup hipster meets classy. Food will not disappoint.
No comment

Perfect for a late brunch in NY. I went last Saturday and they were able to get us in without a reservation, but I think this is rare. The service was fast and the food was out before we knew it. Bread, a bloody mary, and a frittata made for a perfect choice. I loved the energy of the restaurant and it was nicely done inside.  There were people of all ages, dressed up or dressed casually.  The next time I'm in NY I'm going back.

When you come here on an early Sunday morning (as we did recently), expect to find a brightly lit room with large windows, high ceilings and a shiny reflective bar to signal to your inner alarm clock that you should be awake enough to recognize that you are brunching among the most well-heeled of NYC.  At 10 am, the successfull and hard working who live in the area are already out getting a jump on their day by going to this beautiful restaurant.  If the brightness and energy of the room aren't enough to rouse you from your slumber, the piping hot coffee (rich and robust) or the citrusy house made juice of pomegranate, blood oranges and valencia oranges (with just the right touch of sweetness) will.  Sheep's milk ricotta serves as a luscious accompaniment to burnt orange toast (with truffle honey and cracked black pepper intermixed with the ricotta), making this a spread that would be enough alone for breakfast.  Uovo Modenese is an Italian version of Eggs Benedict, with a perfectly poached egg which when you break oozes its warm eggy yolk onto the spinach, sausage and potato hash underneath it, all lovingly caressed with a light tomato hollandaise sauce.  But the stars of the show here at brunch are Karen De Masco's carb-filled creations that assault the senses of sight, smell and taste, all at the same time.  The hazelnut crusted French Toast is a sight to behold, with its crusty exterior studded with hazelnuts and its just slightly underdone interior, all with an eggy sweet flavor that is balanced by an acidic salad of citrus fruits.  One can be forgiven for lapsing into a food coma after a luxurious brunch like this, so when you leave the restaurant, don't feel too bad when you hear the frenetic sounds of a zumba dancing class being held in one of the overhead lofts above you.

Ok so i went here today and the service was great. The staff was very sweet. However, the food...meh! The sheep's mill ricotta and grandmothers ravioli;both signature dishes of the restaurant, were rather ..well sub standard. The bloody mary however was good and the lemon tart was fantastic.

I came to Locanda Verde on a recommendation from a coworker, and I was definitely not disappointed!  My baked eggs were delicious, and my friends loved their shrimp and grits! We topped the meal off with a mango dessert and left so happy and so full.  Not to mention.. the free focaccia bread they give you is so fresh and delicious, I could have made a meal out of just that!

the sunday gravy is so absolutely perfect, i wish it were sunday 8 days a week.  actually it's on the menu so don't worry.  i make one that's pretty damn good, but this was so much better.  loved the gigantone and pumpkin ravioli also.  even a simple argula salad was dressed perfectly and delicious.  loved the lack of pretense, the friendly and helpful service, and the energy of the place.  yum.  i want more pasta!!

This is my favorite neighborhood brunch spot!  I sometimes go really early and order off of the breakfast menu (which is available all week but smaller than their brunch menu) and other times I show up right before the brunch rush and grab a seat at the bar (where they will serve you the full menu).  This is brunch for the adventurous and creative.  Steak tar tar, 12 hour tripe with eggs, Sheep's Milk Ricotta with truffle honey and burnt orange toast (and I'm not a big dairy person and this is AMAZING).  The breakfast stromboli is light and crispy and perfectly matched with poached eggs, fennel sausage, and spinach.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are tangy and moist.  They also have some house made pastries and a little coffee bar for a quick "to go" trip. They make some fabulous unique brunch cocktails as well.   I've been here more than a dozen times, have brought numerous friends and even my picky eaters have found something they love. I could go through almost every item on the brunch menu and not one thing is bad.  No, it's not cheap, but it's worth every penny. I almost don't want to write this review because I don't want this place to be any busier on weekend mornings.
No comment

I have been looking forward to going here for quite some time.  I am an avid Eater reader and they consistently talk about how great this place is and how it is consistently one of the hardest tables to get in NYC, now I see why.  The space is really beautiful, on another occasion I would like to just come and hang out at the bar for a bit.  We arrived on time for our reservation and were sat immediately.  We started off with a bottle of wine and then moved to the appetizers, the arugula salad, the steak tartare, the crab and jalapeno crostini, and the sheep's milk ricotta was what the 4 of us ordered.  Everything was exceptional although I have to say that the sheep's milk ricotta was pretty unreal, it has a whipped consistency to it that makes it really light to eat.  The bread they serve with the ricotta and the tartare is fantastic.  My other favorite was the tartare, I am a huge fan of steak tartare and this was definitely in my top 3 so far.  The flavors worked very well together and everything was extremely fresh because there was absolutely no after taste what so ever.  It was a very clean tasting dish.  For dinner, we ordered the corn ravioli, the branzino, the pork chop, and the halibut.  Also were very good and well executed dishes.  I actually ordered the branzino but I think that the pork chop was the best thing at the table.  They didn't overcook it and it is served medium or so, so it's extremely tender and juicy.  Unfortunately after the entrees we were too full to order dessert.  All in all this was a great experience and I would definitely like to come back, I would also like to pop in for brunch and a drink at the bar.  If you live or are going to be in NYC this is definitely a place that I would go.

During our recent stay at The Greenwich Hotel in Tribeca, we had almost all of our lunches and dinners at Locanda Verde. It didn't take long to realize that nowhere else can hold a candle to their delicious food. My husband is the type who hates to eat in the same place twice and even he agreed that this was a destination restaurant. Their flavors are bright and all of the dishes are highly inspired. Dishes we especially loved were the beet salad with fennel, the foccacia (bread) they give you to start, green pasta with white bolognese, lamb meatball sliders, sardinian and sheeps milk ricotta with fresh herbs and olive oil and grilled country bread, cheese plate, pasta with octopus, pasta with duck sausage, broccoli rabe (so good I had it with each meal! and I usually don't like broccoli rabe!). We also had a great chocolate dessert. If you're in that area, or if you're just anywhere in NYC, do yourself a favor and try Locanda Verde. The only downside is that it's noisy inside. If the weather is good there are several outdoor tables. If the weather is bad, it's worth checking into The Greenwich Hotel where they fast track their food to you in the drawing room. Great people watching at both the hotel and restaurant. Kudos to Mr. DiNiro!
and sheeps milk ricotta.  This place is very refreshing.  My fave brunch and dinner spot so far!
No comment
We enjoyed  this place for lunch / brunch based on a friend's recommendation. The sandwiches were delish, service was very good.  We hope to go back for dinner someday.

I have to say that my review of this place is the exact opposite of Veronique's.  When thinking what I wanted to say about it, the terms "most pretentious restaurant ever" came to mind.  I went here for my mom's birthday with some family and it was not the ultimate dining experience.  We all ordered different appetizers and had wine and some mixed drinks between the 8 people who were there.  They let us sit there for a long time waiting for the 8th person to arrive and the waitress didn't really become bitchy until later on in our meal.  I enjoyed the pasta dish (with ragu sauce) that I ordered.  I usually don't order pasta since I just don't love it but this looked good and I figured at an Italian restaurant it would be a success.  I didn't regret that decision.  However, my dad was fairly annoyed that he paid $23 for 4 scallops.  He kept making fun of his dish and it was a little embarrassing but at the same time pretty funny.  My mom ordered a dessert as did one other person at the table.  Since we were a party of 8 the gratuity was included at a generous 20%.  My uncle told us that that was ruled to be illegal (or perhaps just unenforceable?) in NY state but we didn't fight it.  The service was sooo slowwww in this restaurant.  Our waitress came across as being a mega-bitch after we had been there for a while but this other guy who was new there was super nice and kept coming over to us to check on things.  I think our waitress could tell that we weren't upper class NYers (perhaps just middle class NYers) and she seemed pretty annoyed with the existence of our table.  They brought us more of the delicious pizza-type bread when we asked for it but just putting out plain bread would cut down on their overhead and be just as effective.  We just needed something to munch on while waiting for our food to arrive.    It was really a rollercoaster of an experience (and most likely not worth the $510 price tag) so that is why I will stick with three stars.
No comment

What happened to you Locanda Verde?  I used to love you.  I have been to this restaurant 3 times in the past 3 weeks and after having had consistently bad service at the bar won't be back anytime soon.  The bartenders are rude, snide, unhelpful and if you manage to get their attention they act like they are doing you a favor by getting you a drink.  It was also next to impossible to get anyone's attention when we wanted to order food, and we were never asked if we wanted another drink, even after our empty glasses were sitting on the bar for a while.  It's important to point out that the bar was never crazy busy when I was there and the bartenders (there are usually 3) seemed to love to do anything other than serve drinks: talk to each other, stare off into the distance, wipe down bottles, disappear into a back room, etc.  I still love the ambiance and the comfortable bar seats but it isn't worth the nasty attitude.  Get it together Locanda.
No comment

The place itself is beautiful inside. Just has a very nice atmosphere. The food was way over priced and just okay. The best part of the meal was the free rosemary bread that was served. There are too many good places in NY to try, don't waste your time here.

Had lunch here today. Such a disappointment. I had the ravioli and broccoli rabe. The ravioli was so so, albeit homemade. The flavor wasn't bold. Not worth the price. The rabe was too al dente. The gelato was good, however. Espresso machine was broken. Everyone talks about this restaurant.

the food at this place would make a good cookbook. the food looks really pretty but then it's not worth tasting. it's a pretty space too and was really crowded when we walked in for sunday brunch so it seemed like it should have tasty food.  boo!  i hate wasting calories on mediocre food! i wouldn't bother making a point to go back.

Really awesome food, great ambiance and great service... this is a great new addition to Tribeca!  I don't eat meat and they were really accommodating saying that I could take the meat out of any dish... I had the fig salad without speck and an amazing pesto pasta dish.  A huge thumbs up!

this place is pretty swagged out they have some fire ravioli and balling crostino i got that jawn it was seven dollars but still it was worth it had like mozzarella and pesto and stuff got some pastries they were good i meant they were the cheap ones i hooked up the apple cider donut that was delicious if you go peep their grandma's ravioli super bomb but the best thing i ever hard there was pumpkin squash ravioli that was maybe the best pasta i've ever had this place would be five stars but it's just incredibly good not absurdly good ya feel me?

The dinner was a disaster.  The A/C was obviously not working and the staff response was terrible.  After numerous complaints, the staff made it clear that nothing could be done.  Rather than apologize and do everything possible (i.e. a free glass of wine, dessert, etc), the staff tried to ignore it.  If the food was great, I might even overlook the terrible problem and worst response, but it was average at best.  I'll never return.

Outstanding Italian food, made to perfection, right portion size, well planned, good service. I walked out of there and still thought about the food for the next 3 days. The lamb sliders were to die for, the veal cheeks melted in your mouth, perfection!!! Would go there any day if I lived in the area. Outstanding. Bravo. Bought the cookbook and made 5 recipes, they totally came out exactly as they should. My dinner party guests were wowed.

We went in there to try the pastries from the bakery section and were really disappointed with both the service and the selection. There were about 12-15 items on the menu, but only 5 were available. The servers treated us as though we were wasting their time. We ordered an espresso and a macchiato, which were lukewarm. The blueberry polenta muffin was just ok. We were ignored by the waiter, who poured water for everyone else except us. I don't think I've ever left a place feeling so ripped off. $13.00 for two coffees and one small muffin and really crappy service!? Never again.

Nice bar but very rude door hostess on Saturday night (2/5). So many more friendly places nearby!  We were so turned off by the hostess rudeness (packed restaurant but she said bar was "closed" - at 11:40 on Saturday night???), that my friends and I went to Teroir nearby and spent over $400 there!  My friends were visiting from overseas and I thought this would be a nice place to go for drinks (DeNiro, etc.).  Bravo Locanda Verde! Never again.
Great Italian -ricotta crostini, pasta. Loved the homemade corn ravioli. Terrific service and ambiance.
Love this place - the sheep's milk ricotta is one of my favorite dishes ever, and I've tried a few other similar dishes elsewhere in the city. Atmosphere is great too.
wonderful Chelsea neighborhood brunch/lunch spot. food was deliciousness, service was impeccable.

I called ahead to make a reservation but was told by the male phone host that Locanda Verde are full until 2057 but...that I could show up when they open and get a walk-in table for which they save a few. Planning to go there for my birthday and I showed up on a freezing cold holiday-week Tuesday at 5:30pm. To an empty room! An empty room. (Can I say again all the tables were vacant)? To be told that they had no table for a party of three until 9:30pm. Another couple showed up behind us got the same chilly smug reception. And with a parting gift of wisdom from the female hostesses that perhaps we should all go to the Tribeca Grill (folks in-the-know understand why they try and funnel extra diners to that mediocre dinosaur of christmas past). Nice Try hostess ladies. DO THE WORLD A FAVOR AND BOYCOTT THIS "TO HIP FOR THOU" bulls**t eatery called Locanda Verde. Um...also, the foyer smelled funny. Like gas leak and butane funny. Never eat in a place that smells funny. Rule number one.
No comment

We had a nice meal here.  Though it took a month to the day to make a reservation which was annoying.  The ricotta dip with sea salt and herbs is a must have.  We then had pasta dishes which were excellent.  The grandmas ravioli was very nice too.  Our sea scallops were cooked very well and delicious.  We were so full by desert that we only had a few bites.  It is very pricey but the food was delicious.

Its the second time we visit the restaurant and I can't say anything good about it besides the  nice ambience and okay food. The waiter was very rude and even said we now have to get up and go speak to the manager. When the manager came was still unwilling to help us. They both acted like we were outside a popular club and they dont care since they are so busy. I would not recomend this place.

Condescending, arrogant service.   Inattentive server refused to make any changes to the menu, even for health-allergy reasons.  Said "the chef doesn't make any changes to the menu."  Manager came  by and acknowledged that they cared more about pleasing the chef than pleasing customers and then threw us out for protesting

Called to make a reservation and they asked if they could put me on hold and I said "sure"....they kept me on hold for almost 10 minutes.  Needless to say, I hung up.  I'm sure you would have too.  Guess I'm not going there.

Absolutely worth any wait.  There was a couple leaving the restaurant as we were because they didn't want to wait.  We actually took the time to stop them and encourage them to go back in!!!!!  The lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for.  Their italian style eggs benedict AMAZING.  The fresh squeezed juice wonderful.  My husband wanted to order more food it was so good.  Everything was perfect.  I had heard the waitstaff can be aloof but we felt they were prompt and unobtrusive.  They were there every second but you never felt they were there at all.  We loved it.  Highly recommend it.

The staff was rude, our waitress was HORRIBLE.  The food was OK.  The portions were very tiny as expected.  Everyone at my table was pleased with their meal, but the service just put a bad taste in our mouths.  Take the poles out of your butts and be nice.

Amazing food, we were a party of 2, business lunch, the usherers were really polite and helpful. We were very well taken care of by James, the person serving us, he asked all the right questions and made sure that we were comfortable, he was very efficient, helpful and knowledgeable.I had an Atlantic Cod and my guest had scallops, both dishes were delicious, the Choc Torta and the Lemon Tart was really very well made.

One of my favorite restaurants!  I have only gone for lunch but I have to imagine dinner is just as fabulous.  The wait staff is always on point and the food is top notch.  James P. has been my waiter at least 3 times and he is great.  He makes great recommendations.  When I go it has always been for a business lunch and they are patient waiting for us to get to ordering if we are in deep discussions. The crostino of the day and the sheep's milk ricotta are worth ordering every time.  Plus there is paparazzi parked outside at least once a week, very entertaining!

This restaurant warranted a review from someone who has never reviewed a restaurant before. Everything in this restaurant is great. The design, music, customer service, menu diversification, food quality and taste. I recommend: blue crab, steak tartar, duck, cod, pappardelle. For wine get the fiano avellino.

This is one of my fav NY restaurants - I really love coming here and eating at the bar, great watching the bar staff at work and all the hustle of the restaurant going on behind you.  That works if there are only two of you, so when we returned with friends we sat at a table, usual great food, nice glass of wine, fun evening, but I did pass a jealous glance or two at those folk sitting at the bar......

Quite an enjoyable evening. It is high quality all around - food, service, atmosphere - without being your general stuck-up, high end spot. Our waiter was one of the kindest I have met so far in NY, catering to our needs without being overbearing. Food was amazing, wine selection was vast and varied as far as Italian Wine is concerned. The pasta dishes are smaller than expected, and the meat dishes larger. Has a cafe  in the front, open in the afternoon for espresso and treats, and the bar gets pretty crowded, maybe too much so, after about 8 or 9pm. The bartenders are a bit slow and uneducated in their selection, but if you're not in a rush, they do a good enough job. They make very few tables available for reservations, but leave a number open for walk-ins. at 6:30pm on a Friday, there was a 45 minute wait to be seated without a reservation, and it was a nice day to walk along the water, which is only a block away, and come back just in time to be seated.
Great location.  Really good food.  Our waiter was a pro.  Lots of people make it a lively scene.  I would definitely come back.  Fun spot.

Decided to come back for brunch when my sister was in town. Happy I did. Everything was perfect. The host was kind enough to move us to a better table once it opened up which was great. The server was super friendly and helpful, and service was on point. Food was great and just the right amount to share based on the server's recommendations. Lemon ricotta pancakes were wonderful. Plus we didn't feel rushed at all even though it was Sunday brunch. Major points for that. Thanks so much! Will return again soon.
this place has good, fresh innovative pasta. the atmosphere is also very cute. the wait times are ridiculous, not sure why...but once the hype calms down, i would definitely recommend this place

One of my favorite spots to sit at the bar and catch up with a friend.  It has gotten too difficult to actually make a reservation for anything other than brunch.....I am looking forward to this hopefully losing some hype and becoming a neighborhood spot again, but food is always great and vibe is always warm and friendly.  Ravioli and ricotta are amongst the best dishes on the menu.  Great baked goods and desserts as well.

meh .. leave this for tourists.  sure it's lovely and the food is good but nothing earth shattering - just another celebrity owned, over-engineered place.  the chef from boulud of course is a major talent but seems to be trying to appeal to a baseline that frequents celeb-o-chains that are more suited to miami or vegas. yawn.

I can definitely see this place as a dim, intimate date spot; however, with the high ceilings and the amount of people that pack into this space, you will barely be able to hear your company without straining your ears! The menu items must change occasionally because the dishes that we had a couple of months ago are no longer on the menu now - it's a good thing. The general food quality here isn't amazing, especially not for the price that you pay. We had mussels in garlic white wine, which is good but just about the same as any other restaurant. I had a special of the day cod fish - a small piece of entree with not much of a side on the plate. Desserts did not appear to grab our attention and therefore we didn't get any. I'm not quite sure what the hype is all about, perhaps I just ordered the wrong dishes? It was a bit disappointing to say the least. I hope they come up with better/more creative dishes without leaving the flavors behind!

Probably over-hyped. So if you're reading this, I'm probably doing you a favor - when you go, you'll have more normal expectations and not leave disappointed. I was told this was the best italian restaurant that a number of my friends had been to. I would definitely not go that far. The blue crab crostini was fairly bland, the corn ravioli was decent but also not super flavorful. The steak was cooked really well (sometimes it seems medium rare done right is hard to achieve), so... they've got that going for them. Can't remember dessert, but nothing was so great that I would put this back on my "have-to-return-to" list. Seems as though I did miss out on the ricotta though - bummer.

My friends and I had brunch here this morning. The service was great and the food was ok. We shared the ricotta with honey and rosemary and it was good. I had the frittata and it was just ok. My friends dishes were good as well. I don't know if we will go back, maybe if we are in the neighborhood.

Popped in on a Friday around 5pm, sat at bar. Kitchen opened at 5:30. Bartender was perfunctory and fine. The bar had typical American Food Network crowd ready to launch cute adjectives and show off their "vast" food knowledge. The wines must be tasted of course, with this "savvy" bunch... Ho Hum... Anyway, the same song played over at least eight times while I sipped a prosecco. The stiff financial pretenders next to me commented in a fair way to the bartender, who mumbled something about an Ipod not shuffling... More comments were made as the Twilight Zone monotony of the same U2 song played over again. Normally I wouldn't mind but when you'r e paying 14 dollars a glass for obvious wines that cost ten bucks a bottle, from a luke warm Chef, who's not even there, and the hostesses are giggling about the music, it get's kinda offensive. Is the Ipod locked in the safe? Is president Obama in the midst of an office meeting?  Do I have "fool" written on my forehead? ...Ambiance on a Friday night in Manhattan, was I asking too much?

Absolutely love the breakfast here. Every time I've been here it's been pretty empty and I can't understand it since it seems to get much busier at night. This is probably my favorite breakfast in the city. Best pancakes I've ever had in the ricotta blueberry pancakes with meyer lemon curd. I love everything ricotta and the sheeps' milk ricotta with "burnt" orange toast was fantastic as well. The ricotta drizzled with honey and thyme is plentiful enough that you need a second helping of the toast (which they more than happily give you if you ask). The pastries lining the counter are pretty stellar as well, and are perfect to grab for a snack later on in the day.
solid brunch spot. lemon ricotta pancakes

This restaurant reminds me of Italy.  When you are in Rome or Milan the restaurants char the bread and it is delicious.  That is how they do it at Locanda.  We ordered the bread with the fresh ricotta, it was amazing.  The ricotta had a pool of yummy olive oil in the center and thyme, salt a and pepper.  This is one of the best starters I have ever had, or actually it would be perfect as a dinner entree,.  We also ordered the special ravioli which was stuffed with beef, veal and pork and topped with a fantastic tomato sauce with basil.  Everything was first rate at Locanda Verde.

Under impressed for a place you have to make a reservation at 30 days in advance.  Made a 6:30 reservation for 6 people (the only option even though I called at 8:00 a.m exactly 30 days prior) to celebrate our friend's 60th birthday (here from California).  Loud atmosphere, service with an attitude and we were asked for our table at 8:40.  They offerred a drink to compensate which we declined but still!  Won't rush back.

The one star is for service, not food. The food was really good, however our waitress was rude and totally unprofessional. We went for my sister's birthday and we were really excited about trying Locanda Verde since we had heard so many great reviews. The waitress (short blonde hair, possibly Eastern European)  recommended wine which we didn't care for and her response was "well, you obviously don't know about wine." The drapes were open and the sun was in our eyes so we asked the waitress if she can have the drapes closed just a few inches and she told us to put our sunglasses on. The food was really good but it wasn't enough for me to ever want to go back. In a city like NY where there are so many amazing restaurants with great service, I'm happy to go elsewhere.
Pretty cool scene I guess, but the food was nothing to write home about. I don't think I will be returning.
No comment

Went to LV for lunch. The place was packed and for good reason - the food was great!  I give it 4 stars because th portions, even for the secondi were tiny tiny tiny.  We had the veal cheek special, the pumpkin agniolotti and hangar steak everything was delish! Will definitely go back for a second try, and this time I'll just have to order more food.
yes - consistent good food. good luck getting a spot though! make sure you plan well in advance.

Was presented with fresh, clean napkin (I had not realized mine had dropped on the floor). We were on the wait list for brunch. Instead of chaos though, they were very organized in getting us from our bloody marys to a table. We were not rushed. All the food we ordered, ricotta, ouves mosterne and french toast were all winners. High quality, fresh flavors. It was a fantastic experience. I look forward to going back and trying other items.

Ventured down here for the first time last night, met a friend and dined at the bar (her idea).  Good looking place, sleek bar and lively crowd. We ordered a few apps based on recommendations from other Yelpers and found both the sheeps milk rocotta and lamb sliders to be savory and worthwhile.  However, the pasta with Duck was just OK and the Hamachi, which had a Caponata dressing underneath, was overpowered by this questionable mix...don't bother. Overall, the food was good, service was fair and drinks were expensive, as I just don't get excited about sub-par beverages in the $14-$20 range.  Note: there are also NO 'deals' on the wine list.  As for the young women at the Hostess stand, they could certainly be more welcoming and maybe even a little more bubbly about their employment status.  Lastly, what's the deal with so many staffers in white shirts...there's were probably 1/2 as many workers as patrons??  Worth a try, though nothing to brag about, as there are clearly better and cheaper Italian spots around.

Had eaten here a few times back but never thought it was anything special. Always liked the lamb sliders though. But the last time I ate here, thought the pasta was reallly good. Got the casarecce and the scallops and both were delish. The plum dessert was also really good. Didn't see them on the dessert menu last wk, but a while back they used to have cookies that were super good too
A delicious brunch! Locande Verde offers comforting, classic, New York dining experience.

The service was fine. The food was pitiful and overpriced. I am surprised how many great reviews there are and how packed the restaurant was. We were told that the plates were "sharing size," so the four of us intended to share in that family-style way. I usually don't order salad or an appetizer because I can't eat that much. We each ordered an entree, and they were the size of appetizers or a child's plate! If I shared my plate with the other 3 people, there would be nothing left. I ordered trout, which was overly gamey-tasting and the color of salmon (dark pink). It came with a bit of sauce and garnish - no sides! It was essentially just a piece of fish the size of a deck of cards for $32. Two of the other dishes were similar - a ravioli and veal dish the size of a kid's plate. The fourth diner ordered pork and had two huge slabs of it, but again no sides. We joked that she got lucky! After I finished my fish, I filled up on the focaccia they had brought out at the beginning of the meal. Each of us was still hungry when we left.
Sheep's milk ricotta is my new favorite breakfast! Delicious! Everyone on the staff was exceptionally welcoming, and the space itself has a laid back but classy feel.

Would give it a 3.5 if I could. Steak tartare fabulous, salumi above average, entrees okay. One of us got the halibut, and it looked like they'd culled it with an ice cream scoop -- such a small portion, not at all worth the money. I ordered the duck, which was solid but not mind blowing. Interiors quite nice. They did a great job on the build out. A good dinner for people who like to have dinner in hot, scene-y restaurants, but earnest foodies might be disappointed.
My husband and I went for brunch on a Saturday morning. Food was yummy but service was just ok,  it could have been better.

The food is excellent.  We had a roasted pork belly that was outstanding.  The service was just ok.  The servers and bartenders were all very pleasant, but that's it.  The wine list is amazing; all Italian, and all between 40-120 in cost.  And with very interesting selections.

Great atmosphere-loud enough to keep you awake for that late table, dark and cozy, sexy interior.  And, as has already been said the sheeps milk ricotta is addictive.  I remember this from Avoce and was giddy to find it again.  Other food was good but not as memorable.  One complaint, saw waitress or bartender pour remainder of bottle of wine into another bottle of wine(!) off to the side of the bar-and then put it on the bar!

My Boyfriend and I visited Laconda on Sunday night.  The staff was wonderful, food terrific.  We both would go back to eat there in a minute - the food really was fabulous.  However at $18.00 for a glass of wine, the wine pour was really cheap.  (Two glasses of wine at Locanda is equal to 1 glass at a smiliar Italian venue)  This is the only reason I didn't give Laconda 5 stars.   If we are lucky enough to score another reservation i the future,  we will order a bottle of wine to share.

I went here with my cousin last month and it was packed so we had a drink and waited to get seats to eat at the bar. The food was all delicious. We had the ricotta app to split and it was awesome. Both of our main courses were excellent as well. I also went last summer after it had just opened with a group of friends and the outdoor seating was nice. The fresh pasta still stands out in my mind as being some of the best I've had.

The food at this place is really special... we ordered crab and ricotta crostini at the bar and it was great. Then pappardelle and seafood pasta entrees which were superb 5/5. Only drawback is the service at the hostess stand which was a little spotty. Love the adjacent DeNiro owned hotel. Good thing for 2 hrs of hoops this morning otherwise that would have been good for +3 pounds.

Wow, the 1 month wait to get a reservation here was so worth it. I've been hearing a lot about Andrew Carmellini's spot for quite some time now and I finally had a chance to check it out.  This place was packed on a Friday night. That being said, the noise level was very loud but we didn't mind.  I strongly recommend trying the Sheep's Milk Ricotta, hands down the highlight of my entire meal.  Apparently it was white truffle week in NYC so were given the option of having those glorious little shavings on everything on the menu.  Needles to say, the truffles made the ricotta crostini even better then it was already.  We also tried the lamb meatball sliders (2 small sliders in portion) which I thought were delicious. I also enjoyed the Pappardelle Verde. As for the dinner, I had the steak which was a special for the evening while my wife had the fish. We made the mistake of ordering too much food by the time our entrees came out so I couldn't finish it all but I really did enjoy both the fish and steak. On to the only thing we didn't really like, the dessert. I believe it was the La Fantasia di Caramello. The flavors did not seem to go well and my wife also agreed. She made a point of telling me I made a mistake ordering it. SORRY SORRY SORRY! Other than the dessert, I honestly loved everything about this place and I can't wait to come here again.

I really wanted to award 5 stars but since the Hostess scolded us like we were preschoolers at one point during our meal, I dinged them a star for that. We of course couldn't get a reservation on a Thursday night so we decided to walk in and try our luck. My date arrived early and held court at the bar. I strolled in a bit after 8, grabbed a perfect Manhattan and joined him in the bar area. The place was jammed so standing anywhere in the restaurant definitely had it's challenges but my drink was so yummy I didn't mind. We only had to wait about 30 minutes, which was perfectly acceptable to me. We were seated at a table where I sat on the bench and my date was across from me. Well this restaurant is excruciatingly loud and we couldn't hear anything the other was saying. I suggested that he join me on my side of the table and the thing that I liked was that there is enough space between tables where this wasn't a problem. I'm all of about 100 lbs and my date is about 5'7" and thin. Here comes the annoyance. we were enjoying our conversation when about 20 minutes into our move the Hostess came over and told us that we couldn't sit that way. Now I know that neither of the tables on either side of us complained as they still had plenty of room. What do they do with fat people? Tell them they're too large to sit on the bench? IRKSOME!! The rest of the meal was close to perfection. The cheesy bread they serve to start is warm and crusty, the service is punctual and the food divine. We decided to just order wine by the glass as we had already had a few cocktails, I the Renato Ratti Nebbiolo D'Alba 2010 and my date the Foradori Teroldego Rotaliano 2009. Both glasses were great but I was partial to mine. To start we ordered the Blue Crab with jalapeno and tomato crostini which was incredible. Next we moved on to the Burrata with broccoli rabe, peperonata and pine nuts and it might have been the best burrata I've ever had. I've been wanting to try this restaurant for the 3 years I've lived in this great city but never wanted to try the walk in approach but man is it worth it. My friends that have been insisted I try the Fire-Roasted Garlic Chicken for Two  and they did not steer me wrong. This was perfect and HUGE! The skin was crispy, the meat moist, an extra garlic kick and all served with roasted vegetables. We may be small but we can eat and I don't even feel like we put a dent in it before we cried uncle and had them wrap it up. This is definitely one of my new fav places minus the scolding Hostess. Bravo!!

Made an impromptu visit here after driving back from Locust Valley for some by-the-water lunch and drinks with friends.  Locanda verde was cozy, private and most notably had really comforting food. It was a Sunday evening at 6pmish so I don't think I got the full experience but the food was GOOD. We had this buttery gooey bread appetizer (I think it was the ricotta dish). For my main plate I ordered the beet and goat cheese ravioli which was fantastic. It was a small plate of food but I made up for it with the appetizer... And dessert.  We had the chocolate brioche bread pudding-perfect for sharing and a phenomenal end to the whole meal.
went there with a couple friend last night... apps and entree very good professional service

Sirita-Sirita, you have made the hostess desk as wonderful as the food! I first found this place a year ago, and the service at the hostess desk was terrible, just like others have described. But now that Sirita, with her warm welcoming style, has been hired, there should be no rude receptions. A year ago the hostesses were rude and the Lemon Ricotta pancakes were heaven. I returned for more Lemon Ricotta pancakes on April 23rd, and they were by far the best I have ever had. I did have to ask for a bit more Lemon Curd, which Justin produced very quickly). And with Sirita at the desk and Justin J. taking very good care of us,the overall experience was delightfully wonderful.
Great place to come and eat with the family. A little on the pricey side but certainly worth it. Keep up the good work!

We have been to Locanda a handful of times (so hard to get a res, but so worth the wait), and it is always so good. I think I might have broken a record for most ricotta cheese tostinis consumed on Sat night. We also had the crab one, also delicious. Note: don't eat too much of those (or the hot focaccia) or you won't have room for the rest of the meal. We had a bunch of great dishes - the bolognese (amazing), the halibut, the chicken for two and the arugula and beet salads. Love sitting there too, such a casual but nice vibe.
No comment

This place is always slammed - have come up 2x without a reservation and the wait is insane.  However, the one time I was able to enjoy a meal, it was outstanding.  Really delicious, great atmosphere.  Wait staff was friendly, if not overwhelmed...bill was not as bad as I expected...the decor is pretty good...all in all a great spot and I will definitely come back again.

The food was actually pretty good and the server didn't blink an eye about tweaking a few dishes for me to be more friendly to my diet. This review is much more for the hosts - maybe the rudest guy I've encountered in a while. Couldn't find my reservation and was ready to tell me to beat it...and when he finally did he frowned at me and told me to just wait. This wait was over 20 minutes and we were never asked for our coats to be checked. We were then escorted to a table in a section where (I think) the tables were reserved for walk in customers; we then waited another 15 minutes for the waitress to even talk to us. After that, it wasn't bad at all but I really think they need to work on their customer service.

Interior is very nice, Very spacious with a large bar. We had brunch there and the food was great. The highlight was the pastries/baked goods. Was worth it just to go there for that alone. Definitely worth the hype.
No comment

This was the best brunch I've ever had.  We shared the zucchini frittata, polenta waffles with mascarpone and strawberries and the hazelnut crusted french toast and they were all AMAZING.  The service was wonderful, the atmosphere was great - a perfect blend of rustic and elegant, and the bathrooms were huge and beautiful.  I will go back any time I'm in NYC.  YUM!

I went to this restaurant a month ago and it  is simply wonderful. I tried to get reservations for months but had no luck so my friends and I just tried our luck one night and after a 1 1/2 hr wait we got seated. The atmosphere is divine. The food was delicious. I wanted to go because I read about the pastry chef. Please try her chocolate tart with pistachio ice cream. Also, try the sheep's milk ricotta that comes with delicious crostini. The drinks were great and I was so glad I finally got there. I will go back again and again. It represents and has the feel of the New York I grew up in. Charm and sophistication. Carole
i love this place for lunch. for dinner not so much. to much of a see and be seen place. food is good. lunch is really fun. i dig.

Price might be a little on the high side, but the food does deliver.  We ate outside last Sunday, as the weather was amazing (outside seating is first come first serve, but because we ate early - around 5:30 - there was no problem being seated.)  I took the advice of other reviewers on here and ordered the sheep's milk ricotta crostini.  It was DELICIOUS and there was plenty of bread and ricotta to go around.  The Fava Bean crostini on the other hand was bland and there were just two very tiny pieces.  I'd definiltely pass on that in the future.  I had the beet and goat cheese ravioli and they were pretty good.  For dessert we had the carrot cake which came sort of deconstructed - the cake was by itself and on the side was mascarpone crema and carrot shavings.  All together it was really really good.  The star of the night though was the brussel sprouts with pancetta and pecorino.  I'd go back just for them!

This place is completely overrated. The food is good, but not for the wait or the attitude.  You even have to put your name in to get a seat at the bar and the portions are ridiculously small. I'd say go to Eataly ot Barbuto for better service and food.

Four star food, two star service. I've had to wait for a table even with a reservation. The lamb sandwich (with chickpea frites) is amazing. I could only eat half of it before I was nauseatingly full so the portion size was generous as well.

My wife and I waited months to get into this place but it was well worth the wait. It was perfect in every respect. We were greeted at the front with a warm and friendly smile (no, not from Robert DiNero as I guess he was off that night). Our  server  was attentive but did not hover all over us and he was very helpful with his suggestions. The food was beyond great. We shared everything starting with the sheep milk ricotta. Next we had the lamb meat balls followed by the pumpkin angolotti. For our entree we had roasted Halibut with roasted potatoes and braised endives. The desert was spiced chocolate cake. Each was a "10". Our only question was, can we eat there every day?

Having dined here several times now, I can safely say that this place is consistently fabulous.  I absolutely love the vibe, decor, service and chiefly, the food.  The sheep's milk ricotta is pricey but the absolute best you will ever eat.  The Girondole and the Pumpkin Raviolini pastas are both phenomenal; complex flavors, perfect texture, excellently spiced.  Both are musts at Locanda.  The spiced duck is absolute heaven as is the chicken for 2.  I really could find very little fault with any of the meals I have had here.  The service is not overbearing but the waiters are extremely knowledgeable and will be as involved as you ask them to be.  Locanda Verde definitely deserves its reputation.

how can you enjoy food at this noise level?  insane! And dont sit in the bar area; you will have guys talking on top of your head. Andrew was much better at A Voce on madison.  lamb sliders are meatballs you can make at home as is many dishes.  what's so special about spaghetti with clams?  so the pasta is a la dente; yes, pastas are good but nothing special.  everyone does that. go to perbacco for amazing different pastas.   seriously nothing special here at all and not a single teeny bite of freebie, no amuse, no teeny chocolate; and cheap on the 2 slices of focaccia.   disappointed.
very good food, cool atmosphere.  excellent.

What can I say? One of the best casual restaurants in town. I love Tribeca and was thrilled to have Locanda Verde as part of the neighborhood. Ricotta with grilled bread, lamb meatball sliders, perfectly cooked pasta and the fresh radishes with tuna vinaigrette are all spectacular! Very affordable wine list and good selection of tap beer. Too bad that the popularity are making reservations difficult to come by.

AMAZING. Must call for reservations if they allow you to make them because its always packed. So worth going too. I have been twice now and both times were amazing. This particular time we went for Saturday lunch, I had the lamb sandwich which was like a pulled pork sandwich but with lamb, it was delicious and was served with chickpea french fries, I still don't know how I felt about the fries but the sandwich was delicious...heavy but delicious. My mom had the Trofie pasta and OMG it was SO good. Both these items are off their weekend Brunch menu so they might not be on their regular weekday lunch or dinner menus. BUT the lamb meatball sliders which are on the non-brunch menu are OUT OF THIS WORLD. Also, they are known for this cookie they make, the Nero cookie, have to get one, its delicious too! I will for sure go back here. Enjoy!

We were four ladies on a Saturday night and had a great time.  We each got something different and were equally pleased with our dish.  And even though the restaurant was bustling and lively, the meal still felt intimate thanks to the great acoustics.  Hope to be back again soon.
No comment

So I really wanted to like this place but was pretty disappointed. First, service was iffy. It was just me, myself and I and I was pretty much ignored by my server for larger tables. Don't worry about me- I don't need that glass of expensive wine if you don't care enough to ce and check up on me. On to the food - I had the steak tartare which was bland and served with what I assumed to be garlic bread but was so burnt I couldn't really tell. For an entree I had the Atlantic cod. The cod was edible if not extremely bland but the accoutrements were TERRIBLE!!  The potatoes were crunchy and barely cooked and the artichokes were burnt and tasted like charcoal. Bottom line, I won't be going back.
No comment
No comment

The food was delicous BUT it was too bad that after having to book a month in advance and anticipating a nice relaxing meal, our food came out rapid fire and simultaneously - primi with antipasti, pasta with secondi. Servers hovered about just waiting to grab our plates and sometimes putting a hand on them before we finished.  It ruined the experience.  Diners next to us experienced the same race.  They won't be back and neither will we.

Great ambience, good (nearly great) food that at times seemed a bit dry and heavy.  The bigger issue was the poor service.  And we werent the only one's that have recently had an issue with the uneven service quality according to the hotel next door.

The food was great, but the portion size was lacking. The waitress told me that the portions were for sharing, but it was almost impossible to share one of my 4 pieces of pancetta veal. Enjoy the foccacia bread because that size was NORMAL.
Very impressive place.  Only had breakfast this time, but will definitely return for dinner.  Service was attentive but not overbearing, food was awesome, just a very solid place.

BUT: the two best desserts in this restaurant are now discontinued.  The olive oil cake and the nutella cookies were, by far, the best desserts on the menu.  Both - gone.  I guess they lost their pastry chef - sad.

I went last week for lunch and it was so sensational that I decided to take my family back for a birthday celebration 4 days later!  Pretty much everything we had was sublime and I don't say that often.  The lamb meatball sliders are wonderful (get 2 orders because one is not enough) as are the crostini and the fritto misto.  The highlight of the meal- or I guess one highlight- was the pasta, gigantic in size, with a duck ragout on it.  wow.  everyone also enjoyed the pasta with the wild game sauce and the penne with sausage.  the scallops on a bed of lentils are fantastic also.  We shared the garlic chicken for two, really just a plain roasted chicken au jus with garlic that is delicious but not as exciting as the other dishes.  For dessert we had the semifreddo and the maple custard; both were excellent.   I will be back.

I recently made a reservation for my wife and daughter for breakfast. I had requested that they be seated in the court yard since they both really enjoy dining outdoors. I had spoken to the restaurant on 2 occasions to confirm the reservation and was never told that the court yard was reserved for hotel guests only. Since the court yard was the main reason I had chosen the restaurant it was very disappointing when my wife and daughter arrived and were not allowed to sit in the court yard. In addition the hostess was rather rude in the way she told them. While the food was pretty good the over all experience was a lot less then expected. There is just no reason to treat any guests in such a rude fashion.

Great brunch place.  They've got a great space, excellent service and amazing food.  I had the French toast which was encrusted with tiny crushed hazelnuts and on top there were whole hazelnuts with Sicilian citrus salad (orange & grapefruit sections with mint) and maple syrup.

Very cool place, lots of locals.  It's true that you have to fend for yourself a bit at this place to get some attention (ahhh, there's a list(!) for sitting at the bar - information i could have used sooner, but I wouldn't have met as many people ...).  The food was great - i had the warm mushroom salad and an amazing pork chop, which was a huge portion, perfectly cooked.  Others at the bar were following my leader on this one ...  Totally great place for flying solo - not full of singles, but a friendly crowd.

I had the opportunity to dine at Locanda Verde during a stay at the Greenwich Hotel. I thought it would be trendy beyond belief but it was actually really warm, the staff was really kind, we got a reservation without a problem (could be because we were staying at the hotel) and we really enjoyed the food. We shared the roasted chicken for two which was the best chicken I ever ate and the pastas were really amazing. We loved the meat balls as well. Homey and hip at the same time. A little pricey but you could taste the quality.
No comment

I ate here about a year ago and had a great experience. Great food, good service, etc. So we decided to come back for a special occasion, a 20th wedding anniversary. We made a reservation about a month prior. When we arrived, about 5 minutes early, we waited for about 5 minutes and then were shown to the area in the front where I'm assuming breakfast and coffees are served during the day. Definitely seemed like the no reservation, walk-in area. When I asked if we could be seated in the dining area, I was told that those seats were reserved. I explained  that we had a reservation and the seater then went to the front desk who in a very snarky tone, said the whole restaurant is the dining room. I asked how long we would have to wait for a different table and she said an hour and a half.  Also ordered a salad that had proscuitto and black mission figs. When the salad arrived, no figs. Really? When I asked about the figs, the waiter apologized and came back with a small bowl of figs. Very disappointing in general. Having a reservation,  but seated in the walk-in area really put me off this place. I certainly won't recommend it.

I do not even know where to start. The service here is AWFUL and the food is OK. I lived in NYC for over ten years and love going out to eat and trying new spots. This was my second time back so I feel I can finally review it. The hostesses are the rudest I have ever encountered in any dining experience. If you ask a question, they laugh at you and roll their eyes. I felt compelled to write a review bc I do not understand how this place is still so busy. It is not that great. Last time I went for my sister in law's 35th bday. They brought all our food out cold and forgot her meal. Not only did they not apologize at all, they then brought out her new meal cold and raw too with again, no apologies at all. We were in shock. They just didn't seem to care at all. After brining out cold, undercooked food we all sat there with empty wine glasses and water glasses. We finally said something and the manager came over and didnt seem to care that much either. I do not get it at all. When this has happened at other restarunts like LAVO in NYC the managers have come over, apologized profusely and offered to buy a round of drinks, etc; however, I guess this establishment thinks they are too good for that. If you are considering going -- do not. There are hundreds of other restaraunts so much better, and so much more worth you money!!

Ate brunch with reservations on a Sunday for 12:30.  Front of house was great and friendly and was seated immediately.  Locanda Verde was packed as was the bar.  The tables are a little too close together but was not really a problem for me.  We ordered sheep's milk ricotta with honey and toasted bread and carrot bread as an app.  Both were delicious!! Loved the mellow orange flavor of the toasted bread and the honey in the ricotta.  We also ordered cappuccinos and I had a bloody mary.  Not a fan of the bloody mary, have had much better but the cappuccinos were delish.  I had the scampi and grits and my husband had the breakfast stromboli.  We switched plates mid way and honestly both were very good.  Although the wait staff was pleasant and on the ball, I felt as if the food was being pushed too quickly from the kitchen to the table.  I am not one that normally lingers for hours at a restaurant, but would have liked a little slower pace.  Great decor, great location, great food.....will def be back.

the place is such a total zoo, it really took away from our enjoyment. the  food was fine, some of it quite good like the testa and fava crostini, the pastas, on the other hand, underwhelming.  service a little slow, i guess with all the crowds... i might go back but maybe for lunch or at off-hours
lamb meatball sliders, marry me.

great business lunch place. we ordered the sheep's milk ricotta and lamb sliders for starters and i got the penne pugliese. the pasta was simple and delicious and the starters were very savory. our only complaint was that service took a while, which was especially noticeable during the lunch hour. would definitely recommend.

So this review really goes out to Dolores and Randolph for turning around a horrible experience into loyal guests that will definitely return. We arrived early for our reservation and then waited 15 minutes to be seated, when asked when our table would be ready we were told another 10 minutes (it was actually less, but wow really?). We ordered some coffee- which we would have expected to be much stronger, it wasn't. Anyway, while eating my sister discovered a small piece of plastic in her lemon ricotta pancakes -- not a big deal, I've been in the industry for 7 years... unfortunately it happens - I just did not expect it to happen here. Overall though the food was delicious, we started out with the steak tartara which was really great. Everyone truly enjoyed their entree's as well - they portions were decently sized, everything was fresh, hot and extremely tasty. The service throughout the entire meal was on point, our server was very attentive and truly did whatever he could to meet our needs and make sure that we had an enjoyable brunch. After he could tell we were a bit disgruntled, he sent Dolores over to check on us. Her hospitality could not have been better, not only was she concerned but her concern was genuine. Brunch ended up being on the house and we were given one of every dessert. Of course you can throw free things at people at make them happy, but what really made us happy was her overall concern and desire to make sure that we walked out of her restaurant having a positive experience and wanting to come back. Well, she surely did just that and left an ever lasting impression of how awesome the management team really is at Locanda Verde. Great food and great hospitality -- we will definitely be back very soon!

Was excited to try Locanda and to have a great meal after a long work day. Reservations for 3 on Tuesday were relatively easy to get on the early side, and the service, though a little slow to appear, ended up being very prompt - our food came out quickly. But I'm sad to say that it didn't live up to our expectations. I can't think of anything wonderful about the food here - it was all just okay. We had the ricotta, bruschetta, and fried artichoke appetizers. They were fine, if a little boring, but just terribly small (except for the ricotta, which was plentiful for us - we actually didn't finish it, but had it been tastier, we might have). Given the price of apps, it was just disappointing. For entrees, my table had the ravioli, another pasta with sunday gravy, and the pork chop. The pork looked amazing, but was underseasoned and just slightly overcooked - a shame for such a lovely piece of meat to be rendered dry. The potatoes it was served with could have been any bland, mashed vegetable. The pastas were both fine, but nothing that blew our minds. For dessert we had the deconstructed tiramisu and the sorbets. Both again were fine, but nothing special. With a bottle of wine, our final tab was $200. Just too much money for food just shy of being well executed.
bring back nutella cookies and olive oil cake

Their brunch is by far better than their dinner. The dinner menu while it looks great items are just okay. I do recommend the ravioli, Which has a lot of flavor. I do have to say that the ambience is very nice; But my experience recently with the waiter wasn't a good one. I went with a group of six people and the bill was very expensive.  It was upwards of $250 per person so we all put credit cards down on top of the check to be split evenly. The waitress in a rude manner let me know that they can only take three credit cards. I asked her nicely to them please split the bill into two and use three credit cards on each divided bill. She refused! It went as far as me needing to speak to the manager, because who in their right mind brings $300 in cash to dinner? When I told her that we didn't have enough cash on us she told me to go to an ATM. At a restaurant this nice where prices are high I really did expect that they would accept our credit cards. They did end up accepting it after talking to the manager but I left a bad taste in my mouth.

Could not have had a better lunch. Two of us went on a weekday for lunch and there was a wait; so I'd suggest making a reservation. We shared brussels sprouts, spaghetti squash, and burratta salad. Each I would recommend. The brussel sprouts were served with pancetta and chunks of Parmesan; they came out in an individual size steel baking dish, which was just adorable. They were roasted beautifully, moist, but crisp. The spaghetti squash is another must try! The flavors were so rich, and was rather creamy! The burratta was served with frisee and heirloom tomatoes and almost seemed to have a slight pickled, sweet vinaigrette just lightly drizzled on top. They were very accommodating to allergies as well. The bread served with the meal further exemplified their attention to detail - it was a very thin focaccia with sliced cauliflower on top, so different. The ambiance suited the restaurant because although it was a large space it was inviting and on the minimal end, not too oranate - keeping the attention on the cuisine. Felt very European inspired. The portions were perfect for what we were looking, just enough to sample and share. Though these would be great starters or sides to dishes as well. Although this is a popular spot, we were not rushed what so ever. The food also was served readily. Cannot rave enough about the meal I thoroughly enjoyed here!!

what a cool little spot... the sheepsmilk ricotta is  a don't miss. the  shrimp and grits are a tasty little jewel of  a dish and the hazelnut french toast is light and lovely. this place is billed as a neighborhood bistro. i traveled from bellmore so it was not my neighborhood but well worth the trip!

Mixed review, mostly good.  Dinner on a Saturday night, place was packed & loud, which I tend to like, preferring a party atmosphere to a hushed temple of gastronomy any day.  The good (or I should say, the incredibly awesome):  before dinner we were brought bread which consisted of the most delicious, sinful focaccia I've every had in my life.  I would go back just for that alone.  Seriously.  The lamb meatballs were delicious, the fried artichokes were excellent.  The wine list was really good, but predictably pricey.  The steak tartare was excellent quality & quite tasty, but not particularly noteworthy or special compared to others I've had.  The lemon tart w/lemon granita was very, very tart, so if you like lemon desserts, this would please you.  The carrot cake was non-traditional & my companions weren't into it but I SO was.  Instead of the usual moist carrot cake topped w/cream cheese frosting, this version had no frosting and was actually on the dry side, kinda sorta more like a coffee cake (for lack of a better description).  I actually loved it because I'm not a sugar person & prefer desserts that skew toward less sweet.  The bad:  The waiter informed us that they will only take the full order at once.  In other words, no ordering drinks & apps & lingering while deciding on a main course.  The kitchen wants to control the pace, which I loathe.  And finally, something very strange.  Both my and a friend's pasta dishes were incredibly salty.  I love salty foods, I cook w/lots of salt, and I like highly seasoned food.  My dish was very tasty, but I couldn't finish it.  This was literally a first in my life, not finishing a pasta dish, because I love pasta so much.  Bottom line, do your research in advance in order to secure the best wine & the best price and don't count on LV to change their "ordering everything at once" policy anytime soon.  My strategy for a successful return is to find out when I can get my hands on some of that focaccia & that's when I'll be back, even if it's just for breakfast.

The food is delicious.  No argument there.  The service is horrible.  They have a policy that you must order a "full meal" to dine in the dining room.  As there are never seats at the bar past 5:30, this policy means that even on a 100+ degree day when no one on earth wants a full meal, we were told we had violated the policy by only ordering a $65.00 bottle of wine and two $20.00 appetizers.  They were so rude, they actually hesitated when we asked them if they wanted us to leave!   As the appetizers are priced the same as some of the entrees, this policy doesn't seem to be based on financial reasons.  Why then?  Because it is so popular they can get away with it?  Our waitress was lovely, but the host staff and management were only interested in meeting their own needs.  There is lots of good food in NYC and most of it is served in restaurants where they actually offer hospitality.  I will never go back.

I have been here a few times though last night was by far the best experience. We arrived early as we had  an opening to attend. We were seated at a nice table in the dining room where the ambiance is warm and inviting if a little dark. We ordered, I guess, family style with the intent of sharing each dish. We had two crostini - ricotta and a crabmeat one - which were both fantastic. The ricotta was rich and creamy and the crabmeat was delicate though spiced with a razor thin slice of jalapeno that gave it a crunchy kick. Yum. We had baby kale green salad as well as a bitter green salad which were both tasty. Two pastas which I didn't try but my friends devoured them. Two sides - brussels sprouts with pancetta and cheese and broccoli rabe. Desserts included a chestnut (?) chocolate cake, a lemon tart with some ridiculously delicious gelato (buttermilk I think) and an apple tart-like thing. Wines by the glass and after dinner drinks were all carefully chosen and delish. Service was friendly and fantastic.  A very fun night and one of the bets mealsI have had in Manhattan in a long time. Andare!
